title: [ONLINE] R-Ladies RTP Informal Hangout & Networking
description:
Please join us for an informal hangout and networking hour with other R-Ladies RTP members.

**Topic:** At this meetup, we'll informally talk about what we're working on in R, what we've learned recently, and discuss what we'd like to learn in 2024. This includes discussing events that we'd like to see hosted by R-Ladies RTP for 2024. Come and join the discussion and share your learning goals and wishes for the new year.

**Format:** This will be an informal hour-long Zoom meeting with breakout rooms to discuss a set of discussion questions in small groups. We will also leave time to have unstructured conversation about our experiences programming in R.

**Pre-requisites:** None. This meeting is intended for all R-Ladies RTP members, regardless of your R skill level.

**Code of Conduct:** All events are intended for women and nonbinary people as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women or nonbinary have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

**Contact:** If you have any questions or concerns, please reach out to organizer, Sheila Saia, on meetup.

title: Delavnica: PONOVLJIVA ZNANOST? (reproducible research)
description:
Na tokratni delavnici bomo poskusili:
\- potegnili kodo iz githuba\,
\- ponovili analizo \(narisali graf ali dva\)
\- primerjali rezultate med seboj\!

Vabljeni vsi, ki vas zanimajo orodja za ponovljivo znanost in R!

On this workshop we will :
\- pull code and data from github
\- reproduce 1 or 2 figures made with the data and code
\- compare results\!

Welcome all who are interested!

Geslo ZOOM: RLadies

title: Introduction to reproducible reporting with Quarto
description:
**Join us for a fun workshop that will introduce you to Quarto - an exciting tool for creating reports and websites**

Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system, developed by Posit (formerly RStudio). By combining narrative text, code, images, and tables, Quarto allows you to produce elegantly formatted output that is fully reproducible. Quarto is capable of embedding code written in R, Python, Julia, and Observable JS (for this talk weâ€™ll focus on R). It supports dozens of static and dynamic output formats including HTML, PDF, MS Word, slides, dashboards, scientific articles and more.
In this talk, weâ€™ll discuss what Quarto is and how it differs from R Markdown, demonstrate how to make simple documents, and showcase a few features of Quarto that make it incredibly useful. In this session, you will learn how to:

* create documents in Quarto that combine R code with text, images, and plots.
* make use of Quarto options to easily switch between output formats such as PDF, MS Word, and HTML
* parameterise reports to quickly create multiple copies of a report

\*\*Please bring a laptop so you can fully participate in the workshop.\*\*

After the workshop, we will have ample time for networking and chat over some snacks and drinks (courtesy of the Software Sustainability Institute).

*Nicola is a Lecturer in Health Data Science, based at Lancaster University.*

title: R-ladies New York End of Year Social
description:
Come celebrate the end of the year with R-Ladies New York at our yearly end-of-the-year social! This event will be in-person at the Whiskey Ward 121 Essex St, New York, NY 10002. It will be a great gathering to close out our year!

We want to thank you all for your incredible support and for being part of the R-Ladies community. We hope to see you there!

Drinks will be available for purchase. Dress in casual or holiday gear - we welcome it all!

title: Advent of Code with R-Ladies Philly
description:
[Advent of Code](https://adventofcode.com/) is an annual programming challenge where participants take on (increasingly difficult) puzzles each day from December 1st to 25th.

While you can use **any** programming language, many people challenge themselves to complete the puzzles in R - and you absolutely can solve them all in R!

This is a beginner-friendly event to look at the first 7 days of advent of code and solve some puzzles together! If you are curious about this type of programming challenge, but need that extra push to check it out, then this is a perfect event to attend. We will do a gentle introduction to advent of code and solve a few puzzles together.

This is an online event - full Zoom details will be shared closer to the event.

title: Introduction to R programming
description: R-Ladies Bishkek chapter together with R club of Kyrgyz-Turkish Manas University organizes "Introduction to R programming" course that will last four weeks. Classes will be every Thursday from 12/07/2023 till 12/28/2023. We will be glad to see participants from Bishkek or Kyrgyzstan.

description:

**What**: Networking and socializing over drinks and snacks

We look forward to seeing you there!

title: RLadies Santa Barbra 2023 Wrap-up!
description:
Dear Community,

Join us for our 2023 wrap-up event on **Wednesday, December 6, at Institution Ale**., Downtown Santa Barbara. We will meet from **5:30 to 7:00 pm and do a #TidyTuesday style activity.**

[TidyTuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master) is a weekly social data project organized by the [R4DS ](https://rfordatasci.com/)community. Every Monday, R4DS posts a different real-world data set. The idea is to use this data set to explore and learn new things about working with and visualizing data.

We invite you all to bring your computers, grab a drink and/or snack, and have fun diving into the data set of the week (or any data youâ€™d like). As we code together, we can help and learn from one another.

**Everyone is welcome to join, whether youâ€™re a veteran Meetup attendee or new to R and the Santa Barbara community!** We strive to create a safe and inclusive environment for all R-Ladies events and ask all interested participants to review our [code of conduct](https://guide.rladies.org/about/coc/) before attending.

See you there,
Camila, Danielle & Sam

Ps. We will share the TidyTuesday data of that week here once it is announced.

title: Ten tips for better text: typography meets ggplot and friends
description:
**Join us** for an engaging talk on **transforming data stories** through effective text management, color usage, and dynamic content.

Data Visualization Expert **Cara Thompson** will provide valuable insights and practical coding tips to enhance your data visualizations in R. **Don't miss this opportunity to elevate your data storytelling skills!**

There are often many facets to our data stories, which we need to present succinctly enough for our readers to want to engage with.

In this talk, we will explore how to make text work for us, by first considering how much of it we really need.

Once we've decluttered and explored how we can use colours to be less text-dependent, we'll look at how to optimise text hierarchy in descriptions and in-plot annotations to keep the main thing the main thing, and how to create dynamic content and alignments.

Finally, we'll explore coding tricks to apply these typography tips to tables and interactive plots, giving readers additional information on demand.

Throughout the talk, Cara will share the packages and code snippets used to create and modify plots in R straight from readily available data.

title: Introduction to ChatGPT for R coding
description:
Join us as we welcome Olivia Weng from Washington University in St. Louis for an introduction to using ChatGPT to assist you with your R coding. Learn how to use ChatGPT, step-by-step, to generate R code for preliminary data cleaning and data visualization. This presentation covers data import, descriptive statistics, data cleaning with dplyr, and data visualization with ggplot2 with writing effective ChatGPT prompts.

**You can join in to just watch and learn about this resource, or, if you want to follow along in R and ChatGPT with Olivia, you will need to have installed [R](https://cran.r-project.org/) and [R Studio Desktop](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/) and have a free [OpenAI ChatGPT account](https://chat.openai.com/auth/login).**

To follow along, you also need to download the two datasets that Olivia will use:

* [https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/prasertk/healthy-lifestyle-cities-report-2021](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/prasertk/healthy-lifestyle-cities-report-2021)
* [https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/tunguz/major-cities-of-the-world](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/tunguz/major-cities-of-the-world)

The workshop will be recorded and posted with our other workshop recordings on the [R-Ladies St. Louis YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@rladiesstl7515/videos) page.

title: An basic introduction: Python for R Users
description:
**SPEAKER:**
Wanyin Li is a research student in Psycholinguistics and examines bilingual reading from the University of Birmingham.

**TOPIC OVERVIEW**
I decided to repeat this session at the end of November. Due to the link connection and multiple changes of dates, a few people missed the last session.

R is a language made by and for statisticians, whereas Python is a more general-purpose programming language. Regardless of the background, there will be times when a particular algorithm is implemented in one language and not the other; a feature is better documented.

This workshop helps you cross the R-Python language barrier. Learn about some of the most important data types and data structures in Python and how they compare to the ones in R. We will also cover control flow statements (if-else) for loops and shows you how to write your own functions in Python!

It will be friendly for Python beginners, but we expect you to have some background knowledge of R.

**PREPARATION AND RESOURCES**
There is nothing to prepare in advance.

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The event will be held online and will start at 15:00 on 30/11/2023 (GMT).
Please join us via this Zoom link:
[https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/81953714649?pwd=QzNpaXlMcFpmODFpclFrNFgxdTJQdz09](https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/81953714649?pwd=QzNpaXlMcFpmODFpclFrNFgxdTJQdz09)

**CODE OF CONDUCT**
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: Introduction to base R and ggplot2
description:
***\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\****

**DATE:** TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 28th

**LOCATION:** ROOM 189, 550 RUE SHERBROOKE OUEST (H3A 1B9), IN DOWNTOWN MONTRÃ‰AL

***\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\****

## Details

Join us on **TUESDAY November 28th** for our final meetup of the year!

**Agenda:**

* Settling in and and request for talks
* Speaker
* Networking / practical coding time

**Topic:**
This month we'll be discussing commonly used base R commands and an introduction to the R package ggplot2 for visualizing data.

This session, we will work through exercises related to:

* essential commands in base R (getting started, handling data, etc.)
* visualizing data in graphs using ggplot2
* exploring resources outside of Rstudio/Posit to support your R learning

While this is a more introductory R meetup, all levels are welcome!
Experienced R-users are encouraged to help new R users!

**What to bring:**
Bring your laptop if you'd like to follow along with the examples. We recommend installing the latest version of [R](https://www.r-project.org/) and [RStudio](https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio/) before you arrive.

**Other:**
R-Ladies events always have been and will always be free to attend! RSVPs are not required, but do help us plan space requirements. Please note have changed our location to McGill campus at 550 rue Sherbrooke for this meetup, with space generously provided by the Quantitative Life Sciences department. See above for location details.

**Questions?**
Please comment or message the organizers with any questions.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Holiday graphics and animations in R (in person!)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

The next event is Tuesday November 28, 2023 from 3:30-5pm at FastForward (1812 Ashland Ave #110, Baltimore, MD 21205) at Johns Hopkins Technology Ventures (JHTV). Coffee, tea and cookies will be provided. This meeting will include a group coding event. Pre-pandemic times, we made holiday cards at our November meetup. It was so much fun, that we are going to do it again!

WHO is this for?

* If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
* If you want to learn more about creating data visualizations in R, but don't know how!
* If you want to learn about how to make your own holiday designs in R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA

3:30â€“3:45 Meet & Greet \| ğŸª \| Set\-up

3:45â€“3:50 Who we are \| Announcements \| What's next

3:50â€“4:05 Presentation: Data visualizations with ggplot2

4:05-4:30 Hands-on coding activity: Create your own holiday designs in R!

4:30-4:40 Holiday design showcase!

4:40â€“5:00 Networking -- Any more Qs?

*To benefit most from this workshop*

1. please bring your laptop with
2. pre-installed R & RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/)
3. tidyverse package (https://www.tidyverse.org/)

Having trouble with installation & set-up? Ping us on Slack!

LOCATION:

Enter the 1812 Ashland building and go straight ahead in lobby past the security desk & elevators to Suite #110/JHTV entrance.

FAQ:

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?

A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:

* If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

* email: bmore@rladies.org
* twitter: @RLadiesBmore
* facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RLadiesBmore/
* meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-baltimore/

title: Natural language processing in R
description:
In our next meetup we will discuss NLP in R. We will hear two presentations:

* **Florian Schwendinger**: Introduction to NLP in R
* **Camilla Damian**: Detecting Gender Bias in Children's Books

First Flo will give a general overview of the topic and show relevant R packages (see also the CRAN Task View on the topic: https://cran.r-project.org/web/views/NaturalLanguageProcessing.html).

This will be followed by an application described by Camilla:
*Gender stereotypes form early in the childâ€™s development and are carried over throughout adolescence into adulthood, leaving long-lasting effects which may impact activity and career choices, as well as academic performance. Books, in particular, can have considerable influence, as their characters serve to shape role models of femininity and masculinity for young children. Thus, gender under- and misrepresentation in childrenâ€™s textual literature can contribute to the internalization and reinforcement of stereotypes. To address this issue, we aim to identify and measure relevant dimensions of gender bias in childrenâ€™s books with the aid of both qualitative and quantitative techniques: systematic literature review across disciplines on the one hand and natural language processing (NLP) methods on the other. By exploiting such an integrated research framework, we believe that it is possible to automate the detection of potentially biased text while enhancing the interpretability and transparency of the results.*

title: R-Ladies Lancaster November 2023 Meetup
description:
Welcome to R-Ladies Lancaster! We welcome members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Lancaster exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide.

Our meeting place is Fraser House Hub, in the centre of Lancaster at White Cross Business Park.

We'll have excellent two speakers talking about some of the work they've done using R! More information about speakers and talk topics coming soon!

\*\*\*
Schedule
18:00 - Meet and greet. Grab some pizza and something to drink and meet some people!
18:30 - Introduction to R-Ladies Lancaster
18:40 - Eleanor D'Arcy: Estimating extreme sea levels with R
19:10 - Break
19:20 - Cristine Rauber Oliveira: Never trust summary statistics alone, always visualize your data
19:50 - Wrap up!
\*\*\*

This event is in-person only. Please click "Attend" if you are attending in-person so we can organise food!

title: A Hands-On Tutorial for Visualizing Model Uncertainty with Xiaoying Pu
description:
Ever wondered what an error bar means, or what else you can use?

In this interactive R programming tutorial, you will learn the different types of uncertainty from statistical model outputs, and iterate on visualization designs that depict uncertainty.

Uncertainty is hard, but visualizing it can be easy---with ggdist, an extension to ggplot2 :)

* Use this form to register: [https://forms.gle/4CojHXTmhLmWuQWF7](https://forms.gle/4CojHXTmhLmWuQWF7)
* **This event will be hosted over Zoom.** The link and passcode will be sent by email to those who registered in the form above on the day of the event.
* This email will also include conference materials

This event will not be recorded! It will be a live and collaborative tutorial.

**R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending): [https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct). For questions regarding accessibility, please email [nyc@rladies.org](mailto:nyc@rladies.org).**

description: Ever wonder how to create a map with R. In this tutorial, Ola will take you step by step into making choropleth maps using the ggmap library.

title: TidyTuesday with R-Ladies Philly! (rescheduled to Nov 14)
description:
[Tidy Tuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is a weekly data project where R enthusiasts across the globe share their plots, analysis, and thoughts about a new data set.

It's a great way to get started with R or really stretch your R skills in a fun way and try something new.

At this interactive event, we will facilitate some analysis and live coding of this weekâ€™s tidy tuesday dataset guided by what attendees want to try! You will have a chance to win an exclusive R-related prize if you share a plot, table, or piece of code!

This event is welcome to all. If you are completely new to R, we wonâ€™t be covering installation, set-up, or other introductory topics. However, it should still be a fun event to join and learn by watching!

This is an online event hosted by R-Ladies Philly. For security reasons, we will update the Zoom link on the day of the event.

title: (Even More) Exciting Data Visualizations with ggplot2 Extensions
description:
This time we will have **[CÃ©dric Scherer](https://www.cedricscherer.com/)**, who is a **data visualization designer**, **consultant**, and **instructor** helping clients and workshop participants to create engaging and effective graphics.

Creating effective and easily accessible data visualizations of high quality in an efficient and preferably reproducible way is an essential skill for everyone working in a data-related field.

Luckily, by leveraging the functionality of ggplot2, R users can create highly customized graphics without the need for post-processing â€” and a huge number of extension packages allows you to create even more exciting visualizations and improve your workflow.

In this session, **CÃ©dric** will give an overview of the world of **ggplot2** extension packages and illustrate their usage and benefits by walking you through some examples of more advanced data visualizations and less common chart types.

title: Into to Observable Plot
description:
**Introduction to Observable Plot**

Discover the power of interactive data visualization with Observable Plot, an easy-to-use JavaScript library. This is a beginner friendly talk, no coding required. Together weâ€™ll explore how you can build your own visualizations directly in Observable notebooks and how you can integrate your visuals in Quarto. Data enthusiasts of all levels welcome!

**Presented by Tanya Shapiro**

title: R-Ladies Ottawa Online Lightning Talks
description:
**R-Ladies Ottawa Online Lightning Talks**

Join R-Ladies Ottawa for an online presentation!

**What is it?**

Join R-Ladies Ottawa for three virtual presentations from our committee!

**1: Recreating a visualization with ggplot2**
*Alex McSween & Deirdre Hennessey, Statistics Canada*

In 2021 Canada became the first country to provide census data on transgender and non-binary people. In this presentation weâ€™ll use openly available data, R, and Python to create visualizations inspired by those released [by Statistics Canada](https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/220427/dq220427b-eng.htm).

**2: How to use ChatGPT + GitHub Copilot to help you learn R**
*Melissa Van Bussel, Statistics Canada*

Generative AI is a great tool for learning R, whether youâ€™re a beginner to the language or already an R expert. In this demo, weâ€™ll see how ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot can be used directly from within RStudio to help make writing R code a lot easier.

**3: What an early 2000s reality show taught me about file management**
*Reiko Okamoto, Bruyere Hospital*

Ideas from home organization shows are surprisingly applicable to file management. Using a room divider to establish dedicated zones for different activities in a studio apartment is analogous to creating self-contained projects in RStudio. Likewise, swapping mismatched hangers with matching ones to tidy a closet resembles the adoption of a file naming convention to make a directory easier to navigate.

In this talk, I will share good practices in file management through the lens of home organization. We all know that clutter, whether it is in our physical space or on our machine, destroys our ability to focus. These practices will help R users of all levels create a serene, relaxing environment where they feel inspired to work with data.

**When and Where?**

The event will take place online at 12pm EST on November 9th. Please register in our meetup to receive the zoom link.

**Need more info?**

For any questions or comments please reach out to [ottawa@rladies.org.](mailto:ottawa@rladies.org)

title: Introduction to Network Analysis in R
description:
Please join us for an introduction to social network analysis in R. For this workshop we welcome [Dr. Leslie Echols](https://psychology.missouristate.edu/profile-display.aspx?p=LeslieEchols) from Missouri State University. Leslie has [expertise](https://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=YuFLyNkAAAAJ&view_op=list_works&sortby=pubdate) in social network analysis and its applications to peer relationships, especially relationships among middle-school age children.

Install the **statnet** package ahead of time to follow along.

title: Teaching Computers to See Scatterplots with Scagnostics
description:
Hello friends! It has been a while since our last event and we are excited to announce our next R-Ladies event! Come and join us to learn about how computers can see scatterplots! This will be a hybid event and zoomlink will be posted prior to the event.

As the number of dimensions in a data set increases, visualising its structure and variable dependencies becomes more tedious. Scagnostics (scatterplot diagnostics) are numerical measures that describe the visual features of scatter plots. These features can be used to identify interesting and abnormal scatterplots within high-dimensional datasets and thus give a sense of priority to the variables we choose to visualise. A set of scagnostics is implemented in the `cassowaryr` R package, which provides a user-friendly method to apply these diagnostics to data. The scagnostics have been effective tools in both high-dimensional data visualisation and projection pursuit, which Harriet will illustrate with examples from sports and astrophysics.

title: 4 days workshop
description:
We are holding a four day workshop.We will learn about the R language, its significance, and some of its key packages in these workshops. We will also gain knowledge of data impotation and basic mathematical computation. At last, we'll make a tale from it using various visualization tools.
Participants must bring their laptop, chargers,pens and notebooks.

title: How ChatGPT may affect the future of Data Science
description: In collaboration with R-Ladies Accra and Botswana R User Group, we will look at how the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly evolving, captivating and challenging us with the potential for machines to learn and create. One intriguing advancement in this domain is Generative AI, which has the power to significantly impact programming and data science. In this talk, Ardalan will share what he has learnt from creating DataMotto, a proactive AI for data analysis, and delve into the world of Large Language models, the engine behind tools like ChatGPT. We will explore what Large Language models are, how they are influencing data science, the challenges they present, and the lessons learned from developing a tool that utilizes this innovative technology. Whether you are a data enthusiast or simply curious about AI, join us in this discussion as we delve into the exciting intersection of Generative AI and data science.

title: How ChatGPT may affect the future of Data Science
description:
This is a collaboration between R-Ladies Gaborone and R-Ladies Accra. The speaker,Dr Ardalan Mirshani will discuss how the rapidly evolving field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) intersect with Data Science.
Join us on November 4, 2023 for an interesting and informative discussion.

title: RLadies October Meetup - "R-omics": Using R for bioinformatics
description:
Join us on October 30th for our second meetup of the 2023-24 season!

**Agenda:**

* Settling in and and request for talks
* Speaker
* Networking / practical coding time

**Topic:**
This month we'll be discussing how to use R for bioinformatics. Bioinformatics is a rapidly evolving field that combines aspects of data science, biostatistics, and natural sciences in order to analyze biological datasets. Many research areas can fall under the umbrella of bioinformatics, from modelling the 3D structure of proteins to identifying gene mutations associated with disease.

This session, we will work through exercises related to:

* essential resources for working with genomic data, like Bioconductor packages
* visualizing high-dimensional data such as spatial transcriptomics
* calling command-line tools from R

While some biology background will be helpful for this session, everyone is welcome.

**What to bring:**
Bring your laptop if you'd like to follow along with the examples. We recommend installing the latest version of [R](https://www.r-project.org/) and [RStudio](https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio/) before you arrive.

**Other:**
R-Ladies events always have been and will always be free to attend! RSVPs are not required, but do help us plan space requirements.

**Questions?**
Please comment or message the organizers with any questions.

title: R-Ladies Abuja and Abuja R user Group Meet and Greet
description:
Calling all R enthusiasts based in Abuja--let's chat! We are hosting a low-key event to get to know ourselves. During our Meet and greet, we'll:

* **introduce ourselves,**
* **have lunch,**
* **have some R fun, and**
* **discuss things like how we can support ourselves - career, skills development, book clubs, how should meet, and where, and much more.**

**What to Expect:**
ğŸŒŸ *Storytelling Circle:* In this safe and welcoming space, we encourage you to share your unique R and professional story, challenges, and triumphs. Let's uplift one another by listening and learning from the diverse experiences.
ğŸŒŸ *Networking Opportunities:* Connect with like-minds who are making waves. Expand your circle of support, collaborate on new projects, and find potential mentors or mentees.
ğŸŒŸ *Empowering Activities:* Engage in fun and empowering activities that encourage personal growth and self-discovery. Together, we'll explore ways to harness our strengths and make a positive impact.
**Who Should Attend:**
This event is open to all students and professionals who are passionate about R programming and technology in general. Whether you're just starting your journey or are already a trailblazer, we welcome you with open arms. This inclusive event welcomes professionals of all backgrounds, ages, and experiences. We are committed to creating a safe and respectful environment for all participants.
**Why Attend:**
ğŸŒ» *Form Genuine Connections:* Build authentic relationships with students and professionals who share your commitment to growth.
ğŸŒ» *Supportive Community:* Become part of a nurturing community that celebrates your victories and supports you through professional and academic challenges.
ğŸŒ» *Unleash Your Potential:* Discover new career possibilities, find your voice, and unlock your full potential in a supportive environment.
Let's kickstart a wave of exciting gatherings together â€“ come on over, grab a drink, and let's connect! ğŸ»ğŸ·âœ¨ We can't wait to meet you.

title: Career Development Talk
description:
At our upcoming event, we're putting the spotlight on **careers in data science and statistics**. We want you to be a part of this enriching conversation. If you attend, you'll not only have the **opportunity** to absorb valuable insights but also to actively **engage**. We encourage you to ask questions, **seek advice**, and share your own **career journey**.

Your unique story and questions are invaluable contributions to the discussion, making this event a dynamic exchange of ideas and experiences. We look forward to hearing your voice and helping you navigate the exciting world of data science and statistics careers.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Visualization and analysis of spatial data (Virtual)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is excited to host a meetup on Friday October 27, 2023 from 4-5:30pm (entirely virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have a wonderful presentation from Yi Wang, a fifth-year PhD student in the Johns Hopkins Department of Biostatistics. She will be giving a talk on "Visualization and analysis of spatial data"!

WHO is this for?

* If you are new to R and want to learn about packages to visualize spatial data?
* If you know R, but want to expand your knowledge spatial packages?

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA

* 4:00â€“4:15pm Who we are \| Announcements \| What's next
* 4:15â€“5 pm Presentation: Visualization and analysis of spatial data
* 5â€“5:30pm Networking -- Any more Qs?

Details on the location:

* The Zoom information will be sent to those who RSVP the week before the event.

FAQ:

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?

A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:

* If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

email: bmore@rladies.org

twitter: @RLadiesBmore

facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RLadiesBmore/

meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-baltimore/

title: Reproducible pipelines book club #1
description:
Welcome to the first meeting of our book club! We will be going through the chapters of [â€œBuilding reproducible analytical pipelines with Râ€](https://raps-with-r.dev/) by Bruno Rodrigues.

In this meeting, Julia Romanowska (R-Ladies Bergen) will go through the first three chapters, which are a nice introduction to the topic, and discuss why should we care about reproducibility in the first place.

This will be an online event, and you are welcome to code along and discuss any questions that might arise. We are all learning together!

The meeting will not be recorded.

title: Reproducible pipelines book club #1
description:
First meeting in our book club! We will be going through the chapters of [â€œBuilding reproducible analytical pipelines with Râ€](https://raps-with-r.dev/) by Bruno Rodrigues.

During this first meeting, Julia Romanowska from R-Ladies Bergen will go through chapters 1-3, which make a nice introduction to why do we need to care about reproducibility at all. This will be an online event where you are welcome to code along and discuss any questions or problems that might arise. We are all learning this together!

The meeting will not be recorded.

title: Zero to Quarto: Build your first Quarto website
description:
**Zero to Quarto: build your first Quarto website!**

**Quarto** is one of the most discussed topics in the R community for the past year. In the posit conf 2023 that just happened a few weeks ago, there were 23 (!) talks on this **open-source publishing system**. You can build a personal or organisation website; a course or workshop website; a blog; a scientific report; a presentation; all with the possibility to display and execute code (R, Python, Julia), and for free.

If you:

* don't know what quarto is yet, and want to find out more
* heard of quarto somewhere, but don't know where to start
* are an expert in quarto and want to share your experience

then this workshop is for you!

Join us and our speaker **Chi Zhang** on **Monday, October 23rd** for this exciting event.

**No previous experience with Quarto is required**, just bring your laptop and charger and join us for this creative programming experience ;-)

Wi-Fi will be provided at the event location.

Materials for the workshop can be downloaded or forked from
[https://andreaczhang.github.io/workshop-02quarto/](https://andreaczhang.github.io/workshop-02quarto/)

Program:
18:00 - 18:30 possibility to get support for installing the packages and getting the material necessary for the workshop. If you are an R-beginner and need any type of tech support, don't hesitate to ask us!
18:30 - 18:40 welcome and some ice-breaker questions
18:45 - 19:30 workshop
19:30 onwards: socializing with some drinks at TBD

Event location: KO2-F-153 at UZH Campus

We're very much looking forward to seeing you there!
CÃ©line, Seraphina, Elena and Luisa

title: [ONLINE] Debugging in R with Shannon Pileggi
description:
Please join us for our next meetup with Shannon Pileggi member of R-Ladies Philly on **Debugging in R**!

**Topic:** In this workshop, we will review code troubleshooting tips, discuss debugging functions (*traceback()*, *browser()*, *debug()*, *trace()*, and *recover()*), and distinguish between strategies for debugging your own code versus someone elseâ€™s code.

**Format:** This will be a hands-on workshop in Posit (RStudio) Cloud. This is a special instance of RStudio that you access through your browser. We will share details on how to log in to Posit Cloud to registered participants closer to the event.

**Agenda:** We will open the Zoom room to mingle and make sure everyone has access to Posit Cloud. The workshop will start at 15 minutes past the advertised start time. We expect this workshop to end at 8pm ET.

**Pre-requisites:** Knowledge of how to write a function in R.

**Learning objectives:**

* Review code troubleshooting tips.
* Discuss debugging functions (traceback(), browser(), debug(), trace(), and recover()) and the additional benefits of employing some of these strategies within RStudio.
* Distinguish between strategies for debugging your own code versus someone elseâ€™s code.

**Slides:** [https://shannonpileggi.github.io/debugging-nhsr/#/title-slide](https://shannonpileggi.github.io/debugging-nhsr/#/title-slide)

**Code of Conduct:** All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

**Contact:** If you have any questions or concerns, please reach out to organizer, Sheila Saia, on meetup.

title: R-Ladies Rome - Meet and Greet, October 21st at 6:00 PM CET
description:
Chiacchieriamo! Stiamo organizzando un evento informale per conoscervi un po' meglio. Durante il nostro Incontro e Saluto, parleremo di cose come la frequenza dei nostri incontri e i luoghi. Ci vediamo presto!

Let's chat! We are hosting a low-key event to get to know you all a little better. During our Meet and Greet, we'll discuss things like how often we should meet and where. See you soon!

title: R-Ladies Coffe and Code Hangout
description:
Come join R-Ladies NY for an afternoon of coding and coffee. This will be an informal, hands-on working session where we'll work together on our own projects or tutorials.

Come in curious about a subject or looking to make progress on a project you're working on!

BYOLaptop :) All experience levels welcome!

Some possible things we'll be working on:
\- TidyTuesday
\- web scrapping with rvest
\- making your website/portfolio with R
\- package development
\- analyze and visualize baseball data from \{Lahman\}\, Retrosheet\, PITCHf/x and other sources\!
\- Anything else\! Bring a project or idea you want to work on\!

Find us at the tables in the back of the cafe. We ask all participants to purchase a beverage or pastry from the cafe.

title: Data Happy Hour (with Data Science D.C)
description:
Take a break from your keyboard and join us at Clubhouse in Georgetown for this [Data Science DC](https://www.meetup.com/data-science-dc/) Happy Hour. Come socialize and network with fellow data scientists, analysts, software engineers, and other data enthusiasts.
Chat about your latest project, your job search, or [the package that's solving your LLM/NLP problems.](https://pypi.org/project/marvin/)
We'll also be joined by attendees from the [Government & Public Sector R Conference](https://rstats.ai/gov?utm_source=landeranalytics&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=dont_miss_out_government_public_sector_r_conference&utm_term=2023-09-07) which will in be Georgetown that week (featuring lots of Data Community DC folks)
We'll supply a range of non-alcoholic drinks, with alcoholic beverages available for purchase.

title: R-Ladies Book Club -In Person Only
description:
For our October book club, we are reading "Automating Inequality: How High-Tech Tools Profile, Police, and Punish the Poor" by Virginia Eubanks.

The New York and Brooklyn public libraries have a few copies of this book (hard copy and eBook), but the book is also available for purchase for about $12.

Don't forget to post your questions or reactions on our #rladies_bookclub Slack channel! Not part of our Slack? No problem! Fill out [this form](https://forms.gle/tK4ek5XbN7gLKRJU6) to request an invite.

***

We are happy to have this event be live and in person! This event will be held in person at Arts and Crafts Beer Parlor on 26 West 8th Street, New York, NY 10011. The Google Maps location can be found [here.](https://maps.app.goo.gl/V7hPKxodCc5d4iBU9)

***

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the [R-Ladies Global code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct) (particularly if this is your first time attending!):

title: An Introduction to targets for R
description:
Hi R-Ladies SB!

We are so excited to announce our next workshop: **An Introduction to targets for R**, with Tracey Mangin!

Interested in clean, reproducible workflows in R? Ever get lost in your own workflow? Have you suffered because you changed part of your workflow or one of your inputs but forgot to incorporate it when producing your results somewhere else? Great news, targets can help. In this session we will introduce the R package targets, which is a pipeline tool that coordinates a workflow and only runs "targets" or steps in your workflow that require updating due to downstream changes, saving costly runtime and ensuring that everything is updated when changes occur. This results in more trustworthy outputs and reproducible computation. The session will run as follows:

* Introduction presentation (20-30 mins)
* Short demo (15-20 mins)
* Application (completed individually, in break out rooms, or all together, depending on size of group) (20-30 mins)

**This event will be** **virtual. Please RSVP to receive a Zoom link on the day of the event.**

This workshop will be interactive. To follow along with Tracey's demo and participate in the interactive portion of the workshop, **please fork and clone the following GitHub repository:** [https://github.com/traceybit/rladies-sb-targets](http://clicks.meetup.com/ls/click?upn=XbaZ37larFA-2FuV5MohrYpXag6tzzSKkPkolS2igSlDFbaBDj9506S0APr-2Fk5r-2BnN5DCsh3C7GWZGA9KT-2BuKdvw-3D-3DveVI_uAGIKxVHnzoGVmPcnUwHmR2TNcd1XwKmxiXrbTcDN7iQ2ay5Epo0Q7VJrJTk6vDREdfKvexzTrcowizgD8wSEXny81zzRpmb1yNLjzfDTT9H2ZUh1HgvXFKSavtUYquW34R6GUNDo5vUa1dqKGzmWMdzuu-2Fesx-2FUA4v9j5LZn9J4zsW-2BTdOjkGmiMwOuxtyjxupFqSstOgIagT6t6ij3LDrhniahRIW-2F4dNjg8yYL9pZ-2Fs7YjvEShFZjmUQZYZHJEl2nhJxsLaFknduVsNyus1wm-2FNzOsgkWtZtiXLOvbLxBja9CsHPX-2FfdfcFOEqYdSXWpL8kQPwXktRa6kR2JuZaqk-2FNLXRLlfH6ok5U3PSPCAQa-2BpjrwbvEdRdthbXuDlIovfZD9vDXt5GPDOy-2F8ex14konGP2ZLiWPiXeuG3WVHVIVxsUcTjkuvWTBbalWKawRSXs-2F8aAi-2BBxhOQHBePJNKIycCPedud-2BDjUmDBP94ZbyWr5fa1oyZkABY8DJnphGEOKO89D7DZO0QrgKDg36m-2FDHrbsrrUBqXv-2FMxjE4O7sMjka9Avv6zHefRHEHrMuP4c8XqroTP-2BzvVkaUlV0ue5QHkQODqQrj82cMkHwGfMxhfXPMnP9-2BBJMQ0bjN5ZLNidBqxrvjwuys9p2grnuEN77B-2BK5RmBIseKmbQulq08-3D). If you need assistance with this step, please reach out!

We will be using the following packages: tidyverse, here, and, of course, targets. You can install packages using the following code: install.packages("insert_package_name").

**Important Meetup information:**
To ensure a safe online environment for all, we ask that attendees are aware of the following:

1. RSVPs will close on Wednesday 10/11 at 12:00pm PT. **Please be sure to RSVP before then to ensure admission.**
2. We will send out the meeting Zoom link and passcode to those on the RSVP list on Wednesday 10/11 at 4:00pm PT. **Please be sure to check your email for this information! *The Zoom link and passcode will not be shared publicly on the Meetup page.***
3. We will be cross-referencing names in the Zoom waiting room with the list of RSVPs before admitting folks to the Zoom room. **Please make sure that your Zoom name matches your name on Meetup.**

title: R-Ladies Networking: Building Connections!
description:
Join us for an engaging afternoon of networking at our R-Ladies meetup! Whether you're an aspiring analyst, an R enthusiast, or simply curious about the R ecosystem, this event is the perfect opportunity to connect with like-minded people and expand your professional network.

To kick off the evening and help everyone get to know each other better, we've planned a fun icebreaker activity!

Please note that this time we do not have a sponsor covering the cost of food and drinks. Therefore, attendees will need to purchase their own food and beverages directly from the Southern Cross.

Looking forward to seeing you there!

title: R beginner workshop series - Part 4!
description:
SAVE THE DATE!

RLadies Vancouver will host a 4-week Intro to R workshop series on manipulating, analyzing, and plotting data in R.

This workshop is intended for anyone who:

* has no prior coding experience in R or other languages.

* has little self-taught coding experience.

* is proficient in other languages, such as Python, and would like to transition into R.

More details will be posted here on the content and instructors.

Please RSVP to each individual session so we know how many people to expect. We highly recommend everyone attend all sessions. If you cannot make it one week or just need a refresher on specific topics, we will make the materials available after each session.

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine, Melissa and Cici

**IMPORTANT**\*\*

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

3. I don't identify as one of the "ladies", but can I attend? Of course! Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities and underrepresented people in data science with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To be a part of our community, we ask participants to be actively respectful, encouraging, and supportive of each other.

title: Watch Party Francophone pour la posit::conf(2023)
description:
**En collaboration avec R-Ladies Paris je vous prÃ©sentes le Posit Watch Party!**
**Nous sommes ravis d'organiser une Watch Party virtuelle pour la ConfÃ©rence Posit qui va avoir lieu du 17 au 20 septembre 2023 Ã  Chicago ğŸ”— â€‹[https://posit.co/conference/ ](https://posit.co/conference/)**

**Durant cette Watch Party, nous regarderons les replays de ces deux prÃ©sentations sÃ©lectionnÃ©es de la ConfÃ©rence Posit, le mardi 3 octobre 2023 Ã  partir de 19h00 CEST :**

1. **GitHub Copilot integration with RStudio, it's finally here!, prÃ©sentÃ© par**

**Tom Mock, Product Manager, Posit Workbench and RStudio, Posit, PBC**

**â€œ This talk closes issue #10148, "Github Copilot integration with RStudio", the most upvoted feature request in RStudio's history. Code-generating AI tools like Github Copilotâ„¢ promise an "AI pair programmer that offers autocomplete-style suggestions as you code". For the first time, we'll show a native integration of Copilot into RStudio, helping to build on that promise by providing AI-generated "ghost text" autocompletion with R and other languages. I'll also provide a comparison of Copilot's "ghost text" to a chat-style interface in RStudio via the {chattr} package from the Posit MLVerse team. To make the most of these new features, I'll share some examples of how sharing additional context, comments, code, and other "prompt engineering" can help you go from code-generating AI tools that feel like an annoying backseat driver to an experienced copilot. We'll close with a robust end-to-end example of how these new RStudio integrations and packages can help you be a more productive developer.â€**

2. **Unlock the Power of DataViz Animation and Interactivity in Quarto, prÃ©sentÃ© par**

**Deepsha Menghani, Sr. Data Applied Scientist Manager, Microsoft**
**â€œData visualizations are a key tool in the process of sharing insights with stakeholders in ways that make an impact and are easily understood. Animation and interactivity bring in a key component of analysis that enables one to derive insights that a plot with two dimensions doesn't otherwise allow. Sometimes it can tell a powerful story, and sometimes it can just add some flair to an otherwise low-key story. This talk will showcase packages such as Plotly and Crosstalk that enable this creativity right within Quarto.**
**Plotly, Crosstalk, and Highcharter are powerful packages that allow interactivity right from within your Quarto markdown report, without the need to create an entire application. Easily have two separate plots interact with each other or add drill-down capabilities within a single plot, whichever adds to the story you are trying to tell.â€**

**Mouna Belaid, de R-Ladies Paris, partagera Ã©galement son expÃ©rience personnelle de sa participation Ã  la confÃ©rence et ses impressions. Ensuite, nous prÃ©senterons chaque talk et tiendrons une discussion ouverte aprÃ¨s chaque talk.**

**N'hÃ©sitez pas Ã  partager ce meetup avec toute personne susceptible d'Ãªtre intÃ©ressÃ©e.**

**Ne manquez pas ce privilÃ¨ge d'Ãªtre parmi les premiers Ã  avoir accÃ¨s aux replays de trÃ¨s haute qualitÃ©.**

**Nous vous attendons nombreux Ã  cette premiÃ¨re Watch Party francophone ! âœ¨**

title: Hello, Quarto: A World of Possibilities (for Reproducible Publishing)
description:
R-Ladies Bergen and R-Ladies Cologne are kicking off a series on "**Toolbox for Reproducibility**" where we will dive into tips, tricks, and techniques on how to adhere to best standards and make our code (and workflows) reproducible.

Weâ€™re more than excited to have Mine Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel, professor at Duke University (USA) as well as Developer Educator at Posit, as our first speaker and learn from her how to use Quarto to discover the world of possibilities.

**âœ¨ Hello, Quarto: A World of Possibilities (for Reproducible Publishing) âœ¨**

Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that unifies and extends the R Markdown ecosystem. This talk will introduce you to creating reproducible, computational documents, from course notes to journal manuscripts to books and web pages with Quarto. Familiarity with R and RStudio will be helpful for following along with the demos, however, those who work with any computational documents in any language (e.g., Jupyter Notebooks with Python) will also find the content relevant, particularly since Quarto is language-agnostic and can be used to create dynamic content with any computing language.

If youâ€™re up for joining us, RSVP here. We will share all access details for our virtual event beforehand.

To stay up-to-date with our future events, make sure to also follow us online ([R-Ladies Bergen](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-bergen/) and [@rladies_cologne](https://mas.to/@rladies_cologne@fosstodon.org)) ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

Weâ€™re very much looking forward to seeing many of you! â˜ºï¸

âœ¨ Hello, Quarto: A World of Possibilities (for Reproducible Publishing) âœ¨

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:
Â¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 3 â€œvisualizaciÃ³n de datosâ€ (Â¡QuÃ© bueno, empezamos con grÃ¡ficos con ggplot2 ïŠ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducciÃ³n del libro aÃºn: adelante, es corta, y les darÃ¡ un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reuniÃ³n de organizaciÃ³n vimos un panorama de la introducciÃ³n.

â€¢ En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! Â¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÃS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 3, DE JUEVES DE 18 A 20.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capÃ­tulo nÃºmero 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reuniÃ³n se enviarÃ¡ unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: Highlights of posit::conf(2023)
description:
Join R-Ladies and useR Seattle for this joint event after posit::conf(2023). We will stream select talks from posit::conf and have a lively discussion among the attendees. If you have a specific talk you would like to see, please let use know by messaging the organizer here on Meetup or through our [Slack](https://pmyc0eskne.execute-api.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/Express/). You can find the posit::conf schedule at [https://posit.co/blog/keynotes-and-talks-at-posit-conf-2023/](https://posit.co/blog/keynotes-and-talks-at-posit-conf-2023/)

We will be hosted by the Fred Hutch Data Science Lab on the Fred Hutch Research Center Campus in the Arnold Building.

Afterwards, anyone over 21 is welcome to join us to go to an after-meetup beverage at a local bar. This is not covered by the event.

title: Book Club! More than a Glitch: Confronting Race, Gender & Ability Bias in Tech
description:
Spend Tuesday evening discussing *[More than a Glitch: Confronting Race, Gender, and Ability Bias in Tech](https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262047654/more-than-a-glitch/)* by Meredith Broussard.

**Description:**
*When technology reinforces inequality, it's not just a glitchâ€”it's a signal that we need to redesign our systems to create a more equitable world.*
The word â€œglitchâ€ implies an incidental error, as easy to patch up as it is to identify. But what if racism, sexism, and ableism aren't just bugs in mostly functional machineryâ€”what if they're coded into the system itself? In the vein of heavy hitters such as Safiya Umoja Noble, Cathy O'Neil, and Ruha Benjamin, Meredith Broussard demonstrates in *More Than a Glitch* how neutrality in tech is a myth and why algorithms need to be held accountable.
Broussard, a data scientist and one of the few Black female researchers in artificial intelligence, masterfully synthesizes concepts from computer science and sociology. She explores a range of examples: from facial recognition technology trained only to recognize lighter skin tones, to mortgage-approval algorithms that encourage discriminatory lending, to the dangerous feedback loops that arise when medical diagnostic algorithms are trained on insufficiently diverse data. Even when such technologies are designed with good intentions, Broussard shows, fallible humans develop programs that can result in devastating consequences.
Broussard argues that the solution isn't to make omnipresent tech more inclusive, but to root out the algorithms that target certain demographics as â€œotherâ€ to begin with. With sweeping implications for fields ranging from jurisprudence to medicine, the ground-breaking insights of *More Than a Glitch* are essential reading for anyone invested in building a more equitable future.

This is an event with R-Ladies DC! Feel free to RSVP to either meetup event.

title: R-Ladies Ottawa Networking Event
description:
Join R-Ladies Ottawa for an in-person networking event!
**What is it?**
Join R-Ladies Ottawa for a casual, friendly, and open networking event. Stop by to chat with other women and gender minorities in government, the private sector, or academia who are passionate about R, Python and other open-source tools! Feel free to drop in for as long as you like.
This event (and all R-Ladies Ottawa events!) is FREE.

**Who is it?**
R-Ladies is a group for women and other gender minorities to connect, share knowledge, and support each other as R programmers with the goal of reducing gender gaps in the R community. Note that Python and other open-source programmers are encouraged to attend as well!
This event is for you if you
Â· identify as a woman or other gender minority,
Â· are currently using or curious about R, Python, or other open-source tools (no experience is required),
Â· would like to meet other women and gender minorities who are passionate about R, Python and open-source tools

**When and Where?**
The event will take place in the evening of Tuesday, September 26th. If youâ€™re planning on attending, please register for the event on our [MeetUp](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-ottawa/events/295826281/).
**Need more info?**
For any questions or comments please reach out to ottawa[@rladies.org](http://rladies.org/).

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Intro to data wrangling with palmerpenguins (in person!)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is kicking off an exciting series of meetups starting in Fall 2023! For those new to R-Ladies, R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

Our first meetup this fall will be an in person event on Tuesday September 26, 2023 from 3-4:30pm (615 N. Wolfe Street, Room W2008). Coffee, tea and cookies will be provided. Stephanie Hicks will kick us off with an introduction to data wrangling using packages from the tidyverse with a fun dataset of penguins!

The plan is to be entirely in person (no zoom option) for this event, but we plan to have both types of events (either in person or entirely on zoom) throughout the year (just check the schedule).

WHO is this for?

* If you are new to R and want to learn about packages to wrangle messy data?
* If you know R, but want to expand your knowledge about tidyverse?
* If you think penguins are awesome, and need more penguins in your life!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA

* 3:00â€“3:15 Meet & Greet \| ğŸª \| Set\-up
* 3:15â€“3:25 Who we are \| Announcements \| What's next
* 3:25â€“4:10 Workshop: Intro to data wrangling in R with penguins
* 4:10â€“4:30 Networking \| Any more Qs? \| How to reach us to continue this conversation\!

*To benefit most from this workshop*

1. please bring your laptop with
2. pre-installed R & RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/)
3. tidyverse package (https://www.tidyverse.org/)
4. palmerpenguins dataset package (installation: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/palmerpenguins/

Having trouble with installation & set-up? Ping us on Slack!

LOCATION:
Johns Hopkins School of Public Health
615 N. Wolfe Street
Baltimore, MD 21205

Room W2008 (2nd floor)

Instructions upon arrival: When you arrive at the front desk, inform them you are headed to an R-Ladies event in W2008 and they will give you a temporary badge.

FAQ:

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?

A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:

* If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

* email: bmore@rladies.org
* twitter: @RLadiesBmore
* facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RLadiesBmore/
* meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-baltimore/

title: RLadies 2023-24 Kickoff: Introduction to data wrangling with dplyr
description:
Join us on September 25 as we kick-off R-Ladies for the 2023-24 season!

**Agenda:**

* Welcome and introductions

* Some history about R-Ladies Montreal and request for talks

* Introduction to data wrangling using dplyr

* Networking / practical coding time

For this introduction to data wrangling in dplyr, we assume only a basic level of R knowledge, but all are welcome. If you are proficient in R, we encourage you to attend for the planning, networking, and ideally to help out your fellow useRs! Ideally come with R and RStudio already installed, as well as the dplyr package, but we can help troubleshoot as needed.

The event will be held at WeWork L'avenue, on the 5th floor just past reception.

Please comment or message the organizers with any questions.

R-Ladies events always have been and will always be free to attend! RSVPs are not required, but do help us plan space requirements.

title: R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks - RSVP and Call for Speakers
description:
We are excited to host an online version of one our most popular events - R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks!

**Fill out this brief form by Friday, September 8th** to submit your application to be a speaker!
[https://forms.gle/mK1wGiFaNFX43vh99](https://forms.gle/mK1wGiFaNFX43vh99)

***What are lightning talks?***
Lighting talks are five minute talks. You can talk about anything R, Python, Tech, and/or Data Science related. Looking for ideas? How about talking about a cool package you found, how you use R in your company, a favorite learning resource, your journey into Data Science, or a side project you've been working on?

We would especially love to hear from people who've never presented at a meetup or conference before and/or those who still don't feel confident speaking publicly. A lightning talk can be a great way to start out speaking, as it's quick, low-prep, and fun!

Interested in proposing a talk but want to brainstorm ideas, get feedback, or some encouragement? We're here to help! You can join the #lightningtalks channel in our slack channel or email nyc@rladies.org. We would be happy to set up a time to talk with you!

To celebrate the diversity in the R Community, we're prioritizing presenters who identify as a minority gender (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).

***Important Dates***
\- Submissions due: Friday 9/8
\- Notification of acceptance: Wednesday 9/13
\- Speakers to Confirm Participation: Friday 9/15
\- Submit slides to R\-Ladies: Friday 9/22
\- Lightning Talk Event: Sunday 9/24
\-\-\-
This event will be hosted over Zoom -- the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event, and the passcode will be shared via email.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: Mastering R II: The Journey Continues
description:
We are thrilled to announce the sequel to our highly successful "**Mastering R: An Intensive Crash Course for Data Enthusiasts!**" Building upon the foundations we laid in the crash course, we invite you to embark on the next stage of your R programming journey with "**Mastering R II: The Journey Continues**."

**Course Overview**: In this exciting follow-up course, we will revisit the basics of R, reinforcing your understanding of its core concepts. But that's just the beginning! We'll also dive headfirst into the world of data wrangling, where you'll learn how to clean, reshape, and prepare messy data for analysis.

**What to Expect**:

* **Back to Basics**: We'll refresh your knowledge of R programming, ensuring you have a strong foundation to build upon.

* **Data Wrangling Mastery**: You'll become proficient in data wrangling techniques, a crucial skill for any data analyst or scientist.

* **Basic Modeling Techniques**: We'll introduce you to the fundamentals of modeling, allowing you to make data-driven predictions and decisions.

**Who Should Attend**:

* Anyone who completed our R Crash Course.

* Data enthusiasts looking to deepen their R skills.

* Those interested in practical data wrangling and modeling.

**Why Attend**:

* Solidify your R skills.

* Gain mastery in data wrangling.

* Understand the essentials of modeling.

* Join a vibrant learning community.

title: An introduction: Python for R Users
description:
**SPEAKER:**
Wanyin Li is a research student in Psycholinguistics and examines bilingual reading from the University of Birmingham.

**TOPIC OVERVIEW**
R is a language made by and for statisticians, whereas Python is a more general-purpose programming language. Regardless of the background, there will be times when a particular algorithm is implemented in one language and not the other; a feature is better documented.

This workshop helps you cross the R-Python language barrier. Learn about some of the most important data types and data structures in Python and how they compare to the ones in R. We will also cover control flow statements (if-else) for loops and shows you how to write your own functions in Python!

It will be friendly for Python beginners, but we expect you to have some background knowledge of R.

**PREPARATION AND RESOURCES**
There is nothing to prepare in advance.

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The event will be held online and will start at 15:00 on 22nd September 2023 (GMT).
Please join us via this Zoom link:
[https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/85814328424?pwd=TkhicHdJaG90dXRQdnVWM1dtU1VYdz09](https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/85814328424?pwd=TkhicHdJaG90dXRQdnVWM1dtU1VYdz09)

**CODE OF CONDUCT**
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: R beginner workshop series - Part 2!
description:
SAVE THE DATE!

RLadies Vancouver will host a 4-week Intro to R workshop series on manipulating, analyzing, and plotting data in R.

This workshop is intended for anyone who:

* has no prior coding experience in R or other languages.

* has little self-taught coding experience.

* is proficient in other languages, such as Python, and would like to transition into R.

title: postit::conf(2023) R-Ladies Reception
description:
R-Ladies Chicago and R-Ladies Global are excited to co-host an R-Ladies meet-up at the conclusion of posit::conf(2023)! This event is open to the public, so it is **open for both attendees of [posit::conf](https://posit.co/conference/) as well as community members who are not registered for posit::conf**.

* Announcements from the Global Team

151 E Wacker Dr
Chicago, IL 60601

The ballroom is on the ground floor of the hotel. In the lobby, there's a prominent restaurant called the "American Craft Kitchen & Bar", Plaza Ballroom is directly behind that.

title: Project Oriented Workflows
description:
Join us for our first workshop of the 23-24 season to learn about project oriented workflows in R!

The learning objectives of this workshop are:

* Establish the concept of the project as the basic organizational unit of work. RStudio offers rich support for this way of working via projects.
* Describe benefits of project oriented workflows.
* Apply best practices for working in RStudio projects, including
* Creating robust file paths that travel well in time and space (someone else's computer, your computer a year from now) with base R and with the {here} and {fs} packages.
* Constructing human and machine readable file names that sort nicely.
* Differentiating workflow elements, analysis inputs, and analysis outputs in project structure to create navigable programming interfaces.
* Restarting R frequently, with a blank slate.

Link will be added closer to the event

title: AnÃ¡lisis multivariado para datos biolÃ³gicos, un primer acercamiento.
description:
Se viene un nuevo meetup y no te lo podÃ©s perder.

El objetivo de este meetup serÃ¡ conocer y poner en prÃ¡ctica algunas de las tÃ©cnicas mÃ¡s usadas del anÃ¡lisis multivariado aplicadas a datos biolÃ³gicos, de manera de facilitar su comprensiÃ³n y uso. El anÃ¡lisis multivariado intenta encontrar patrones de similitud entre objetos sobre la base de las variables utilizadas. Estos patrones permiten formar grupos cuyos objetos son mÃ¡s similares entre sÃ­, que con los objetos integrantes de otros grupos. AdemÃ¡s, el anÃ¡lisis multivariado busca identificar aquellas variables que permiten discriminar dichos grupos de objetos. Los patrones resultantes del anÃ¡lisis multivariado permiten contrastar hipÃ³tesis sobre las relaciones entre los objetos y explicar la causalidad de los agrupamientos, como asÃ­ tambiÃ©n predecir objetos y variables todavÃ­a no descubiertos.

El taller serÃ¡ presencial y virtual y se realizarÃ¡ el miÃ©rcoles 30 de agosto de 10hs a 12hs en el edificio de INIBIOMA (Pasaje Gutierrez 1400, Bariloche).

Para asistir al meetup, primero por favor lean nuestro [CÃ³digo de conducta](https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md#spanish)

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R y los paquetes instalados, los cuales se enviarÃ¡n 3 dÃ­as previos al taller.

A quienes asistan presencialmente, recuerden traer su taza/mate y si quieren, algo para compartir!!

Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

Por cualquier consulta bariloche@rladies.org.

title: The 3 Rs of R Coding: Reduce, Reuse, and Reproduce
description:
This workshop is designed for individuals who want to learn how to set up their R analysis workflows to maximize efficiency and reproducibility. If you find yourself struggling with really long Rmd files and getting lost in long scripts, this is for you!

Topics such as reducing script length through vectorization and functional programming will be a focal point. Additional topics such as version control and code organization will be discussed.

In the second portion of the workshop, we will work through some real examples demonstrating ways that messy scripts can be improved for readability and shareability (either people on your team or your future self!).

The workshop will be suitable for beginner to intermediate R users or for those who are new to the concepts mentioned previously and are looking to go beyond the basics. Some familiarity with R or another coding language would be helpful and assumed but not required, so novice users are encouraged to attend.

Those who are highly experienced in R or have experience working on R development teams may already be familiar with many of the topics covered but are welcome to attend and offer their own input and perspectives.

**Date: August 29**
**Time: 6 pm ET**
**Location: Zoom details for joining will be added**

**About our Speaker**
Anastasia Lucas is currently a PhD student in genomics and computational biology at the University of Pennsylvania but has previously worked as a research data analyst in various industry and academic positions. Her work in R has focused on data cleaning, statistical analysis, package development, and data visualization.

title: R/Bioconductor watch party for #BioC2023
description:

ğŸ‘¥ We're thrilled to announce our upcoming **in-person event** at **R-Ladies Rome**, Italy. Mark your calendars for an enriching experience as we gather together to explore the world of Biostatistics data and R programming.

ğŸŒ **Details**:

We will be watching selected talks from the **Bioconductor Conference 2023**, covering a range of bio/data science-related topics, including:

* Biostatistics Workshops: how to use R with Galaxi Cloud

* Demo of selected new Bioconductor packages

* Tips & tricks for managing large data

We will kick off at 4 PM CET, dedicating the first hour to delving into some of the captivating #BioC23 talks. Our agenda is designed to make the most of our time together, connect with fellow data enthusiasts, ensuring an engaging and rewarding experience for all!
