title: Working with JavaScript in R
description: During this meetup, we'll be exploring the two languages - R and JavaScript with Bilikisu Olatunji, to understand their fundamental differences as a language, and their strengths and weaknesses. We then take a look at combining the two to see the advantages and how they support each of their respective limitations to produce a useful application like R's Shiny dashboard.

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

At this event, we'll revisit one of the Tidy Tuesday datasets from June 2023 on global energy use made available through Our World In Data's Energy Data Explorer (https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/energy). You can read more about it here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2023/2023-06-06/readme.md.

Agenda (all times in ET):
6:30 - 6:45 pm Meet & Greet
6:45 - 7:45 pm #tidytuesday
7:45 - 8:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out [this blog post](https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and [the main repository page](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Summer Mix and Mingle
description:
**UPDATE 8/21:** The weather looks like it's clearing up in time for our Mix & Mingle tomorrow, so we'll meet as planned on the beach in front of Cabrillo Pavilion at 5:30pm!
____________________________________

Join us at East Beach (in front of Cabrillo Pavilion) to kick off our year of events with an R-Ladies mix & mingle -- get to know other local R-Ladies in a less-technical setting. Weâ€™ll spend some time enjoying our beautiful Santa Barbara weather and views, and get to know each other through low-stress, facilitated networking activities.

All R-Ladies are welcome, whether youâ€™re a veteran Meetup attendee or new to R and the Santa Barbara community. We strive to create a safe and inclusive environment for all R-Ladies events, and ask all interested participants to review our [code of conduct](https://guide.rladies.org/about/coc/) before attending.

Weâ€™ll provide some light snacks and refreshments, but we encourage you to bring some to share if you are able to.

Looking forward to connecting with you all!

Your R-Ladies SB co-organizers,

Sam, Danielle & Camila

title: R-Ladies Social / Post-Cascadia R Conference
description:
Join us for a social after Cascadia R Conference!

Cascadia R Conference is an R conference serving the Pacific Northwest (OR/WA/BC). This event is a place to come together around R and get together with like-minded people across the region. Interested? [Learn more on their website and register today](https://cascadiarconf.com/)!

The conference concludes at 6 pm on August 19th. Afterwards, we invite R-Ladies to join us at a social gathering. Come even if you didn't attend the conference. It's a great time to meet and chat with other R enthusiasts from the area!

We will share the location closer to the event. Please note, each member will be responsible for covering their own food expenses. We appreciate your understanding and hope to see you there.

title: oRganized: how do you structure your R-work?
description:
How do you oRganize your R work?

Let's talk tools, workflows, strategies and share how we structure our work with R!

Join us on **Wednesday, August 16th** for an **informal networking event** around this topic.

We'll meet at **18:00 in front of the Landesmuseum** and find a spot at Platzpitz park. We'll provide some snacks and beverages, just come as you are and share your experience and questions!

In case of bad weather we'll update you about an alternative location.

We're very much looking forward to seeing you there :)
CÃ©line, Seraphina and Luisa

title: Hacknosis: Optimizing Patient Experiences
description:
# The Challenge

Gaps in healthcare still exist and the need for better solutions to bridge those gaps is critical. Today, more than half of the worldâ€™s population lives one to two hours away from a doctor. The pandemic taught us that telehealth can be a great option. It allows patients and doctors to maintain routine contact and, therefore, good healthâ€”but only if the right tools are available. The challenge faced by health providers is how to incorporate new technologies that enable doctors and patients to have real conversations, supported by a simple experience.

### This is where you come in.

Developers are out-of-the-box thinkers, so we need your help to improve the flow of information between patients and doctors and identify ways to provide better patient support, regardless of their location.

### Tech Stack

* Teams may use any tech stack of their preference
* The tech stack should include a combination of cloud technologies, data & analytics, and artificial intelligence
* OpenText cloud APIs MUST be a key component of your solution

***

**Thank you for participating! We invite you to participate in one or all of the challenges identified. If you would like to combine multiple challenges into a super solution, submissions will be accepted and will be judged based on the use cases.**

### Task

* Develop a solution using OpenText API's
* Deployment of project on Github or Postman

***

### Submission format

* Project description (mandatory)
* Presentation (mandatory â€“ can be either a video or document)
* Link to the project

title: Debugging in R with Shannon Pileggi
description:
We are excited to announce our upcoming event with the extraordinary [Shannon Pileggi](https://www.pipinghotdata.com/) on ***Debugging in R***!

Learn how to unlock your programming superpower with debugging techniques! In this workshop, we will review code troubleshooting tips, discuss debugging functions (*traceback()*, *browser()*, *debug()*, *trace()*, and *recover()*), and distinguish between strategies for debugging your own code versus someone elseâ€™s code.

**Format:** This will be a hands-on workshop in Posit (RStudio) Cloud. This is a special instance of RStudio that you access through your browser. We will share details on how to log in to Posit Cloud to registered participants closer to the event.

**Agenda:** We will open the Zoom room to say hi, mingle and make sure everyone has access to Posit Cloud. The workshop will start at 15 minutes past the advertised start time.

title: [Online] Lessons from COVID-19: Non-random Missing Data and Its Consequences
description:
R-Ladies NYC is co-hosting a webinar with [Data Umbrella](https://www.meetup.com/data-umbrella/)!

A fundamental challenge for survey and observational datasets is that not all records in the dataset are complete; key pieces of information may be missing. This talk will work through the models and methods from the paper [MODELING RACIAL/ETHNIC DIFFERENCES IN COVID-19 INCIDENCE WITH COVARIATES SUBJECT TO NON-RANDOM MISSINGNESS](https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.08161).

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
How to Join the Webinar
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
You can join via your browser (no app download required). Use Chrome or Firefox. Pre-register for the webinar:
[https://www.bigmarker.com/neo4j/Data-Umbrella-Webinar](https://www.bigmarker.com/neo4j/Data-Umbrella-Webinar)

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Video Recording
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
This event will be recorded and placed on Data Umbrella's YouTube. Videos are usually up within 24 hours of the event. Subscribe to their [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/c/DataUmbrella/) and set your notifications.

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Time
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
9 am PT / 12 pm ET / 16::00 UTC / 7 pm EAT / 9:30 pm IST

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Additional Details
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
**Talk Level:** Intermediate
**Pre-reqs:** Familiarity with statistical modeling, ideally survey statistics and Bayesian inference.
**Prep Work:**

1. [Modeling rates of disease with missing categorical data](https://epibayes.io/publication/2022_trangucci_zelner_etall_modeling_rates/)
2. [Multiple Imputation of Missing Data](https://www.bookdown.org/rwnahhas/RMPH/mi.html)

**Resources:** [https://github.com/rtrangucci/epi-missing-data](https://github.com/rtrangucci/epi-missing-data)

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Connect with Data Umbrella

title: Mastering R: An Intensive Crash Course for Data Enthusiasts!
description:
If you're looking for a powerful and flexible tool for data analysis and visualization, then look no further than R! Join us and learn how to use R for your data analysis!

This open-source programming language is packed with features and functions that can help you make sense of mountains of data. Whether you're a statistician, data analyst, or data scientist, you'll find that R is a versatile and indispensable tool in your arsenal.

With R, you'll be able to perform complex calculations, manipulate data, and create stunning visualizations with ease. But that's not all! R is also perfect for creating machine learning models, performing advanced statistical analyses, and so much more.

The community of R users and developers is vast and dedicated, making R one of the most popular data analysis environments in the world.

The best part is that it's free and continuously updated with new functionalities to meet your every need.

And for those who are just getting started with it, fear not!

title: Unlocking the power of community data
description:
In today's interconnected world, communities generate an astonishing amount of data through their interactions, activities, and shared experiences. This data holds the key to unlocking insights, identifying patterns, and shaping strategies that can revolutionize numerous sectors, including healthcare, education, urban planning, and social services.
"Unlocking the Power of Community Data" will illuminate the pathways towards utilizing this vast resource effectively. Attendees will have the opportunity to learn from experts who have successfully harnessed community data to drive innovation, foster collaboration, and address critical challenges.

title: Swirl Package in R
description:
The Swirl package in R is a valuable tool for enhancing the learning experience of R users. It provides an interactive and hands-on approach to mastering R programming through a series of interactive lessons and exercises. This abstract explores the features and benefits of the Swirl package and its significance for R users.
The Swirl package serves as a self-paced learning platform that offers a wide range of interactive courses covering various topics in R programming. These courses are designed to guide users through step-by-step lessons, allowing them to practice coding directly within the R environment. Swirl provides immediate feedback, quizzes, and challenges, fostering an engaging and immersive learning experience.
One of the key advantages of the Swirl package is its flexibility. Users can choose from a diverse set of courses tailored to different skill levels and areas of interest. Whether you are a beginner seeking a foundational understanding of R or an experienced user aiming to expand your knowledge, Swirl offers courses suitable for all levels.
Moreover, Swirl allows users to learn at their own pace and convenience. It eliminates the need for external resources or expensive training programs by providing a comprehensive learning experience within the R environment itself. This accessibility makes it particularly beneficial for individuals looking to enhance their R programming skills without investing in additional learning materials.
Additionally, Swirl promotes active learning and retention through its interactive nature. Users are encouraged to actively engage with the lessons, complete exercises, and solve real-world problems. This hands-on approach not only improves understanding but also builds confidence in applying R programming concepts in practical scenarios.
The Swirl package also fosters a sense of community among R users. Users can share their progress, seek help, and collaborate with fellow learners through online forums and communities. This collaborative environment provides a support network where users can seek guidance, exchange ideas, and celebrate achievements.
In conclusion, the Swirl package in R is a valuable resource for R users, offering interactive and self

title: Intro to git/github workshop (in person)
description:
Join R-Ladies Philly for an in-person interactive workshop on version control with git & GitHub with amazing presenters, Shannon Pileggi and E. David Aja!

In order to actively participate in this event, you will need to complete some pre-work to ensure you have a GitHub account as well as the necessary credentials in place to explore this workflow.

If you are unable to complete the pre-work, you may still attend the event as an observer rather than as an active participant.

Pre-work:

1. Please be ready with current versions of both R and RStudio. This means R>= 4.2.0 and RStudio >= 2023.03.0 Build 386, unless you have a good reason otherwise. See the discussion in Install or upgrade R and RStudio: [https://happygitwithr.com/install-r-rstudio.html#install-r-rstudio](https://happygitwithr.com/install-r-rstudio.html#install-r-rstudio)
2. Complete the pre-workshop Git/GitHub set up instructions: [https://happygitwithr.com/workshops.html#pre-workshop-set-up](https://happygitwithr.com/workshops.html#pre-workshop-set-up)
3. Install VS Code ([https://code.visualstudio.com/](https://code.visualstudio.com/)), optionally with R language support ([https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=REditorSupport.r](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=REditorSupport.r)).

Learning objectives

* Employ version control via git and GitHub with operations including commit, push and pull.
* Fork and clone from remote repositories.
* Describe the importance of viewing commits and diffs.
* Compile markdown reports from an R script for sharing code products on GitHub.
* Create a project web site via GitHub Pages.
* Compare and execute different methods to re-visit previous versions of projects.
* Utilize branches as safety nets for code experimentation.
* Explain situations that can create merge conflicts and strategies to resolve them.

Agenda:
5:30 pm - arrive, get settled, and grab some food!
5:45 - 7:15 - session 1
\-\- break \-\-
7:30 - 8:30 - session 2

title: Panel on Data in the Media Industry (RSVP in Event Description)
description:
Ever wondered what data jobs exist in the media industry? What it's like to work in audience analytics, as a data journalist, or business analytics at a publishing company? R-Ladies is hosting a panel to help answer these questions! Our panelists work at the New York Times, Bloomberg, and Penguin Random House, and they can provide insights around working as a data scientist in media.

**\*\*\*IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT RSVPs\*\*\***
Please RSVP using the following [Google form](https://forms.gle/m1s47n3D11Qzt9cf9) (https://forms.gle/m1s47n3D11Qzt9cf9) so we can reach out to you about zoom link details closer to the event date.
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Event Timeline
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

* **4:00pm - 4:10pm: event introduction and panelist introductions**
* **4:10pm - 4:45pm: 35 minutes of prepared questions**
* **4:45pm - 5:00pm 15 minutes of audience questions**

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Speakers
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
**Hayley Arader** *is the Director of Audience Analytics at the New York Times, where she leads a team in using data to better understand and reach our readers. Before the Times, she worked at Civis Analytics as a Data Scientist and then Data Science Lead, where she and her team supported political campaigns and organizations with modeling, targeting, ad testing, and message research. Hayley graduated from Harvard University with a BA in Government and Statistics, where her research focused on identity and voter behavior. From research to politics to media, Hayley has written a lot of R code, and spent way too much time with ggplot.*

**Madeline Campbell** *is a data reporter at Bloomberg and she works on projects around the newsroom regardless of beat. Previously she worked in data science/analytics for a health research institute, tech company and political campaign. She is mostly a Python user but dabbles elsewhere.*

**Sophia Tee** *is a seasoned data science professional with over a decade of experience in the industry. Currently, she is a Director of Data Science, where she leads efforts in marketing attribution and automation of advertising workflows. Sophia's journey into data science began when she transitioned from financial operations at a hedge fund to pursue a career that allowed her to make greater and more thoughtful impact. Since then, she has been deeply involved in creating and delivering data science initiatives. In addition to her professional contributions, Sophia is committed to supporting the next generation of data scientists. She enjoys mentoring younger professionals and helping aspiring data scientists develop the skills they need to succeed*.

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): [https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct)
For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: Conferencia: Roles en la GestiÃ³n Del Dato

title: 3 Reasons to Use Tidymodels with Julia Silge [Seminar]
description:
Please join us July 13th for a virtual seminar on '3 Reasons to use Tidymodels' by Julia Silge!
Modeling and machine learning in R involves a bewildering array of heterogeneous packages, and establishing good statistical practice is challenging in any language. The tidymodels collection of packages offers a consistent, flexible framework for your modeling and machine learning work to address these problems. In this talk, weâ€™ll focus on three specific reasons to consider using tidymodels. We will start with model characteristics themselves, move to the wise management of your data budget, and finish with feature engineering.

**All members who RSVP and attend the event will be entered into a raffle and 3 winners will be chosen to receive a free eBook or hard copy of Tidy Modeling with R by Julia Silge and Max Kuuhn (2022)**

Zoom link TBA.

title: One Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses
description:
Get ready for an electrifying presentation!
**R-Ladies Rome** presents: **Dr. Laura Kahn** \- One Health Initiative

**Dr. Laura Kahn** will talk to us about the building blocks of public health that emerged during her research for the highly anticipated book, "**One Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses**". We will be examining coronaviruses from a One Health perspective.

The One Health concept recognizes the interconnectedness of human, animal, and environmental health, particularly in the context of emerging zoonotic diseases like coronaviruses.

Get ready for an eye-opening discussion on how underappreciated building blocks are transforming public health policy and the implications of global events that follow.

This talk is not to be missed!

\-\-\-\-\> [One Health Initiative](https://onehealthinitiative.com/)

\-\-\-In Italian

Preparati per una presentazione elettrizzante! La **Dottoressa Laura Kahn** ci parlerÃ  dei principi costitutivi relativi alla salute pubblica, emersi durante le ricerche per il suo attesissimo libro: "**One Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses**". Preparati per una discussione illuminante su come elementi di base ancora sottovalutati stanno trasformando le politiche della salute pubblica e le implicazioni di Globali che ne conseguono. Non mancare!

title: Build your first web app with R Shiny
description:
Get ready for our next workshop on **building web apps with R Shiny**!

We're thrilled to have a very special speaker for this session: **Olajoke Oladipo** will guide us through the exciting world of Shiny apps, and you will be able to get practical help with building your (first?) app.

**No previous experience with Shiny apps is required**, just bring your laptop and charger and join us for this creative programming experience ;-)
Wi-Fi will be provided at the event location.

Materials for the workshop can be downloaded or forked from [https://github.com/rladies-zurich/shiny101](https://github.com/rladies-zurich/shiny101)

Program:

18:30 - 18:40 welcome and some ice-breaker questions
18:45 - 19:30 workshop
19:30 onwards: socializing with some drinks at ["Kleine Freiheit"](https://kleinefreiheit.ch)

Event location: room KO2-F-153 at RÃ¤mistrasse 71 Â· ZÃ¼rich

We're very much looking forward to seeing you there!
CÃ©line, Seraphina and Luisa

title: Web scraping with R
description:
Workshop details
This intro to web scraping will teach you how to use the rvest package to scrape data from Wikipedia. We will be working with data about celebrity/notable deaths since 1990 to analyse the â€œ27 Clubâ€ phenomenon.

Date and time: June 29, 2022 at 6:00pm
Webinar link: RSVP to view the link (password follows \`?pwd=\` in the link)
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmine

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine and Melissa

**IMPORTANT**\*\*

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready
2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
3. Who is allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

Speakers and Talk Titles:

* â€˜Shiny for Production Appsâ€™ by **Angela Minster**
* â€˜Leveraging Open-Source Communities for Professional Developmentâ€™ by **Hebah Bukhari**
* â€˜Imaging R: An Interactive Web Application for Visualizing Multimodality Imaging Data Using R and Shinyâ€™ by **Kiki Zhang**
* â€˜Data wrangling in R for SAS usersâ€˜ by **Priyanka Gagneja**

title: R-Ladies Lightning Talks: 2023 edition!
description:
Join R-Ladies DC and R-Ladies Philly in June for an evening of short and insightful talks related to using R. Topics will highlight the breadth of use cases our members solve using R and the packages they love.

We will update the zoom link before the event.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 - Join online
6:10 - 6:15 - Welcome and announcements
6:15 - 7:30 - Talks

Speakers and Talk Abstracts (in order of presentation):

* â€˜Data wrangling in R for SAS usersâ€˜ by **Priyanka Gagneja**
*This talk is about how to make it easy to translate legacy SAS codes with R. This can be a good starting point for SAS programmers who don't know much R and for R users who do not know SAS.*

* â€˜Leveraging Open-Source Communities for Professional Developmentâ€™ by **Hebah Bukhari**
*A few years ago I made a career switch and picked up R as a coding language. I didnâ€™t have any coding background before. I began in an accredited program, but everything I learned about R and coding has been through the contribution of the R community and the help of its generous members.*

* â€˜Imaging R: An Interactive Web Application for Visualizing Multimodality Imaging Data Using R and Shinyâ€™ by **Kiki Zhang**
*I developed an R-based web application that provides interactive image processing, analysis, and visualization. Multimodal data can be explored intuitively through the analysis pipelines comprising spectral density and time-lagged cross-correlation analyses for quantifying variation in neuronal dynamics and observing interaction dynamics patterns between signals.*

* â€˜Using the OpenAI API With Your Prompt + Your Dataâ€™ by **Abigail Haddad**
*I'll show how I'm using the R openAI package to work with the GPT-4 API. My example involves creating fake resumes by combining custom prompts with job-related data from a .csv file, showing how we can use the API to iterate through a dataset for text generation. I'll also mention a couple of NLP projects that I'm doing that use the same general format of prompt + iterating through text.*

* â€˜Tidyverse Style Guideâ€™ by **Arati Krishnamoorthy**
*A guide to using the tidyverse style guide.*

title: Resources to begin your journey with R
description: The Carpentries teaches foundational coding and data science skills to researchers worldwide. All our lessons are available under a Creative Commons license, so anyone is welcome to use them as they wish, provided they attribute them back to us. Our curricula range from data organisation with spreadsheets and data cleaning with OpenRefine to some analyses and plotting with R or Python. We have lessons for more advanced users focussing on visualization in R, working with core data structures, using conditionals and loops, writing custom functions and running R programs. Join this session to explore our various resources to begin your journey with R.

title: Structural Equation Modelling of the World Happiness Report
description: This webinar focuses on the application of Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) to analyze the World Happiness Report. SEM is a statistical technique that allows researchers to explore complex relationships between variables and test theoretical models. The webinar will cover the key concepts of SEM and its relevance in happiness research. It will demonstrate how SEM can be used to examine the factors influencing global happiness and provide insights into the intricate relationships between various variables, such as GDP, social support, and life satisfaction. Attendees will gain a deeper understanding of the World Happiness Report and its underlying statistical framework.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Data intervention for NGS analysis and R pkg dev (Virtual)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is excited to host a meetup on Thursday June 15, 2023 from 4-5:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have a fantastic presentation from Dr. Mercedeh Javanbakht Movassagh, an Associate Research Scientist with a focus on infectious disease computational biology and bioinformatics, at Yale School of Medicine. She will be giving a talk on data intervention strategies for various Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) analyses and R package development!

WHO is this for?

* If you are new to R and want to learn about packages to analyze genomics data?
* If you know R, but want to expand your knowledge Next Generation Sequencing?

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

title: Data Science Best Practices
description:
Don't miss out on this exciting event featuring [Dr. Simina Boca](https://github.com/SiminaB), a renowned statistician and data scientist with extensive experience in both academia and industry. Dr. Boca will be covering a range of topics related to data analysis and data science projects, providing valuable insights and practical tips for attendees.

During her presentation, Dr. Boca will discuss the different stages of data analysis, offering expert advice on how to effectively organize and manage data science projects. She will also delve into the importance of reproducible research, highlighting key principles and best practices for ensuring that research can be replicated and verified.

But that's not all! Dr. Boca will also provide an introduction to exploratory data analysis, discussing basic principles and techniques for visualizing and analyzing data. Attendees can expect to gain valuable insights into the process of data analysis, as well as practical tips and strategies for managing data science projects and conducting reproducible research.

Whether you're a seasoned data scientist or just starting out in the field, this event is not to be missed. Dr. Boca's presentation promises to be a valuable resource for anyone interested in data science, statistics, or related fields. So mark your calendars and join us for an exciting and informative event with Dr. Simina Boca!

title: Intro R Workshop (hybrid)
description:
Join the Seattle R-Ladies in this 2-hour workshop where we introduce you to R and RStudio at the beginner level. In it, we cover:

* R and RStudio including projects, scripts, and packages
* The help function
* Reading in data as a data frame and RData
* Data types

This is a hybrid workshop. Virtual attendees will receive a Zoom link the day of the workshop.

**Pre-requisites**
You **do not** need any prior experience in R or coding!

**Materials**
[https://bigslu.github.io/workshops/introR.workshop/introR.html](https://bigslu.github.io/workshops/introR.workshop/introR.html)

* Estructuras de bucle en R: For para iterar sobre una secuencia de valores; while para iterar mientras se cumpla una condiciÃ³n; repeat para crear blucles infinitos.

* En R existe la familia de funciones apply(); lapply(); sapply()...

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Intro to Causal Inference in R using fixest (Virtual)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is excited to host a meetup on Monday June 5, 2023 from 4-5:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have an awesome presentation from Dr. Berk Can Deniz (@berkcdeniz, https://www.linkedin.com/in/berk-can-deniz) , a Data Scientist at Figma.

Causal inference's popularity has exploded in academia and industry in recent years. As causal inference's importance grew, R has been one of the most important platforms where cutting-edge methods and packages are created and used. In this session, we will go over popular causal inference methods such as instrumental variables and differences-in-differences, and explore how to apply them in R.

WHO is this for?

* If you are new to R but want to learn more about packages you can use to estimate parameters in models?
* If you know R, but want to expand your knowledge about causal inference and how to implement these ideas with code?

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

title: R-Ladies Book Club
description:
For our May book club, we are reading "The Theory That Would Not Die: How Bayes' Rule Cracked the Enigma Code, Hunted Down Russian Submarines, & Emerged Triumphant from Two Centuries of Controversy" by Sharon Bertsch McGrayne. This book is separated into five parts, spanning 17 chapters. We will focus on the first three parts (the first 10 chapters).

The New York and Brooklyn public libraries have a few copies of this book, but the book is also available for purchase (prices range around $10-$15).

Don't forget to post your questions or reactions on our #rladies_bookclub Slack channel! Not part of our Slack? No problem! Fill out [this form](https://forms.gle/tK4ek5XbN7gLKRJU6) to request an invite.

***

This event will be held over zoom and the link and password will be shared the morning of the event.

***

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the [R-Ladies Global code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct) (particularly if this is your first time attending!):

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TIDYVERSE? BY PROFESSOR MINE Ã‡ETINKAYA-RUNDEL
description:
**Please register for online or in-person event via SSA official link: https://www.statsoc.org.au/event-5169700**
Attending in-person is limited to 50 attendees so please make sure you register via the link above and **not** from Meetup.

**What's new in the tidyverse?**
The tidyverse is an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science. One important feature of the tidyverse is that packages in the tidyverse share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures. Another important feature is that the tidyverse is a living, breathing, and evolving ecosystem. In this talk I will discuss what is new in the tidyverse, highlighting tips and tricks for what's new in the tidyverse in 2023. Additionally, I will take a broader view of "new" and discuss major updates and new features in the tidyverse that got implemented between the 1st and 2nd editions of R for Data Science.

venues.name: WEHI - Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research

title: Level up your plots, with Cara Thompson
description:
**Join us for a fun workshop that will help you take your plots to the next level**

If you've used ggplot2 a few times, but you're looking to spice up your graphs with more advanced features, then this workshop is for you. Here is what we're planning to do:

* Explore how to be less dependent on annotations by using intuitive colour palettes
* Illustrate ways in which we can use text colour and fonts to add text hierarchy
* Add in story-enhancing annotations and data highlights to draw attention to the key data patterns
* Package up bits of reusable R code
* Introduce you to {ggtext}, {geomtextpath} and {gghighlight}

You'll make the most of the workshop if you come prepared with a plot that you have created before but aren't entirely happy with. During the workshop, you'll be given time to apply the learnings to your own plot(s).

\*\*Please bring a laptop and the code for your less-than-perfect plot so you can fully participate in the workshop.\*\*

After the workshop, we will have ample time for networking and chat over some snacks and drinks (courtesy of the Software Sustainability Institute).

*Cara is a Data Visualisation Consultant based in Edinburgh, with a background in academia. She specialises in helping research groups and data-driven organisations communicate the insights from their work through clear and compelling visualisations. She's a regular contributor to the online #rstats community and has earned a solid reputation for making complex things easy to understand.*

title: Joint May Event RLadies x Vienna<-R
description:
We are happy to announce Bettina GrÃ¼n and Benjamin Schwendinger as the speakers for our next joint event with the ViennaR meetup group! They will talk about the following topics:

1. **Benjamin Schwendinger** will talk about the 'data.table' package, which is a widely used, high-performance extension of base R's 'data.frame'. In this talk, we will cover the latest development steps of the package over the last few years. We will also shed light on how 'data.table' gains its speed and how useRs can ensure that it is used to its full potential.
2. **Bettina GrÃ¼n** will be giving a talk on R Packages, walking us through important guidelines for extending R with packages. This talk will be interesting for R package developers and useRs alike.

title: Add JavaScript data viz to your data science toolkit with Observable Plot
description:
**THIS IS A RESCHEDULED EVENT!**

**Important Meetup information:**

To ensure a safe online environment for all, we ask that attendees are aware of the following:

1. RSVPs will close on Wednesday 5/24 at 12:00pm PT. **Please be sure to RSVP before then to ensure admission.**
2. We will send out the meeting Zoom link and passcode to those on the RSVP list on Wednesday 5/24 at 4:00pm PT. **Please be sure to check your email for this information! *The Zoom link and passcode will not be shared publicly on the Meetup page.***
3. We will be cross-referencing names in the Zoom waiting room with the list of RSVPs before admitting folks to the Zoom room. **Please make sure that your Zoom name matches your name on Meetup.**

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

Hi R-Ladies SB!

We are thrilled to welcome Allison Horst & Ananya Roy for our first ever ***JavaScript*** lesson using Observable Plot -- this hands-on workshop-style event may be a slight departure from our R-based meetups in the past, but fear not -- you can expect to see hints of {ggplot2}'s influence in this new-to-us tool!

Please see Allison & Ananya's event description below for more details, and note that this is a **virtual-only event** (Zoom link will be distributed closer to the event).

Be sure to fill out [this fun survey](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScspHfdtwddLsVhJEEywUEIXE7CM6Zt7qsVn8kRVgdvxGZb0g/viewform?usp=send_form) if you haven't already (seriously, it's fun and had us laughing through it all) by Monday 5/19 @ 5pm PT so that we have a rad dataset to explore during the workshop!

See you there!

\~ Sam, An, Danielle, & Camila

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

**Description:** We're increasingly seeing different languages and tools combined in computational notebooks. For example, Quarto makes it possible to add Observable JavaScript to .qmd documents, creating exciting opportunities to include custom interactive data visualizations for the web alongside your R code and analyses. How can you get started with data visualization in JavaScript?

In this session, we'll introduce [Observable Plot](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot) \- a JavaScript package with a goal of getting you to "a meaningful visualization quickly\." In particular\, we'll highlight how your grammar of graphics and ggplot2 knowledge maps closely onto Plot code\, and explore how Observable Inputs get you quickly from static to interactive web\-ready visualizations\.

**Beforehand:** We'll be working in Observable notebooks. If you want to save your work from this session, you can create a free account at [observablehq.com](http://observablehq.com/). Or, you can follow along and make changes to our shared notebook without creating an account to test it out (in that case, your changes just won't get saved).

**Pre-meetup fun survey:** We want to explore some data that feels relevant. *Can you help us out?* We've made this [fun little survey](https://forms.gle/LxFupn6wM7KBcqrH6) to build a play dataset for use during the session. Thank you for filling it out by **5pm PT on Monday 5/19!**

title: R-Ladies Philly: Analyzing Experiments Using Causal Forests
description:
**This is an R-Ladies Philly event. RSVP on their meetup page to get the Zoom Link: [https://www.meetup.com/rladies-philly/events/292812621/](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-philly/events/292812621/)**

**R-Ladies Philly Event:**
Please join us May 17th for a virtual workshop on 'Analyzing Experiments Using Causal Forests' with Elea McDonnell Feit, Associate Professor of Marketing at Drexel University.

Randomized experiments that compare two "treatments" are used in dozens of industries from clinical trials in medicine to A/B tests in marketing. Traditionally, statisticians have focused on the \*average\* effect of the treatment. However, we know that not everyone is average. Causal Forests is a powerful machine learning method used to find subgroups that have different (heterogeneous) treatment effects. For example, in a medical study patients with different health conditions may respond differently to a treatment. Causal Forests allows us to find those subgroups even when we have many different variables describing the patients and we don't know which ones are related to the treatment effect. Causal Forests can even be used to obtain a causal estimate of the treatment effect from observational (non-randomized) data. Elea will provide and overview of the algorithm and demonstrate how it can be implemented in R using the [grf](https://grf-labs.github.io/grf/index.html) package. By the end of the talk, attendees will have a solid understanding of the theory and implementation of Causal Forests and be ready to apply this method to their own research.

**PRIZE ANNOUNCEMENT:**
RSVP and get entered into a raffle for a FREE eBook titled 'Tidy Modeling with R' By Max Kuhn, Julia Silge (2022). 3 winners will be chosen at the end of the workshop. If you already RSVP'd then you have been entered into the raffle. Must RSVP before the event begins to be entered in the drawing and must be present to receive the prize!

title: Why I Hate Summer Time: Coordinating a Global Community of Learners
description:
Join us for an intriguing discussion on time zones and scheduling challenges with [Jon Harmon](https://twitter.com/JonTheGeek)! Are you tired of the hassles that come with summer time? Jon will provide valuable insights and practical tips for managing time zones and scheduling events for a global audience.

As the [Chief Community Manager of R4DS Online Learning Community](https://www.rfordatasci.com/), Jon is an expert in mentoring and coordinating a diverse group of R learners. In this event, he will share his experience of leading a global community of R enthusiasts at all skill levels, working together to improve their abilities.

By attending, **you will learn from Jon's leadership and guidance and take your R skills to the next level**. You will also have the opportunity to network with other R learners and experts. Don't miss out on this incredible opportunity to enhance your understanding of time zones and R!

In qualitÃ  di Chief Community Manager della R4DS Online Learning Community, Jon Ã¨ un esperto nella formazione e coordinazione di un gruppo diversificato di apprendenti di R. In questo evento, condividerÃ  la sua esperienza nel guidare una comunitÃ  globale di appassionati di R a tutti i livelli di competenza, impegnati insieme per migliorare le loro abilitÃ .
Partecipando, imparerai dalla leadership e dalla guida di Jon e porterai le tue competenze di R al livello successivo. Non perdere questa incredibile opportunitÃ  per migliorare la tua comprensione dei fusi orari e di R! Vi aspettiamo numerosi.

title: Leveraging ChatGPT in R
description:
Join us for an exciting talk on leveraging ChatGPT in R, presented by our guest speaker, ChatGPT. This talk is brought to you by R-Ladies, an organization dedicated to promoting gender diversity in the R community.

In this 45-minute talk, ChatGPT will share insights on how you can use the power of ChatGPT to improve your R programming skills and streamline your workflow. You will learn how to access and integrate ChatGPT into your R projects, and discover its full potential as a language model.

Following the presentation, there will be a Q&A session where you can ask ChatGPT and other attendees any questions you may have. Don't miss this opportunity to learn from one of the most advanced language models in the world and connect with fellow R enthusiasts. All skill levels are welcome, so come join us for a fun and informative evening!

title: Estructuras condicionales en R
description:
\*\* DescripciÃ³n
Este taller te permitirÃ¡ aprender a manejar las estructuras de control en R, un aspecto fundamental en la programaciÃ³n para automatizar tareas repetitivas o condicionales. A lo largo de dos horas, veremos cÃ³mo utilizar las estructuras de control mÃ¡s comunes en R, como el bucle for, el bucle while y las estructuras if-else. AprenderÃ¡s a escribir cÃ³digo eficiente y legible, evitando la repeticiÃ³n innecesaria de cÃ³digo y mejorando la legibilidad de tus programas. El taller estÃ¡ dirigido a personas con conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R. Al finalizar el taller, los participantes tendrÃ¡n las habilidades necesarias para aplicar estructuras de control en R a sus propios proyectos y anÃ¡lisis de datos.

\*\* De la ponente
La Dra. Mirna Vazquez Rosas Landa es investigadora en el Instituto de Ciencias de Mar y LimnologÃ­a de la UNAM, donde se dedica a estudiar la vida microbiana del ocÃ©ano. Su trabajo se enfoca en explorar preguntas sobre biogeografÃ­a, evoluciÃ³n, ecologÃ­a y fisiologÃ­a de los microorganismos. Utiliza enfoques computacionales y experimentales para responder a estas preguntas y su interÃ©s principal es entender cuÃ¡les son los factores que determinan la distribuciÃ³n de las especies microbianas en el ocÃ©ano, entre otros. AdemÃ¡s de su trabajo en la investigaciÃ³n, la Dra. Vazquez tiene una pasiÃ³n por enseÃ±ar y compartir conocimientos. Es co-organizadora de RLadies Xalapa desde el 2018 y es una instructora activa en la Comunidad de Desarrolladores de Software en BioinformÃ¡tica y en la Red Mexicana de BioinformÃ¡tica.

title: Introduction to Bayesian GLMs with brms
description:
**SPEAKER**
This online workshop will be led by Dr Bodo Winter (https://bodowinter.com/)(@BodoWinter). Bodo is a Senior Lecturer at the University of Birmingham, UK, and the author of the leading R book "Statistics for Linguists: An Introduction Using R". (I Highly recommend getting oneğŸ¤©.). We are thrilled to have Bodo again!!ğŸ¥³ğŸ¥³ğŸ‘ğŸ‘

**WORKSHOP OVERVIEW**
For this workshop session, Bodo intends to walk people through the core insights of the generalized linear model (GLM) framework, with an emphasis on Poisson regression and logistic regression, two approaches that are incredibly useful when analyzing discrete data. We will work on two examples of experiments involving co-speech gestures and fit both types of GLMs.

**PREPARATION**
Knitted markdowns will be provided, but attendees who want to run the models themselves should install the packages â€œtidyverse,â€ â€œbrmsâ€ and â€œtidybayesâ€ packages. Unfortunately, brms installation can sometimes be tricky. Please attend even if you donâ€™t get it running, as youâ€™ll still be able to benefit!

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The workshop will be held online, starting on 11th May at 16:00 (UK time). Please join us via this Zoom link:
[https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/87984238119?pwd=VDBLSGFsckJBbC9YT08xY05kazZMUT09](https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/87984238119?pwd=VDBLSGFsckJBbC9YT08xY05kazZMUT09)

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: Exploratory data analysis and visualisation
description:
Exploratory data analysis (EDA) is a critical (and sometimes under-appreciated!) step that precedes statistical analysis. This includes steps like calculating descriptive statistics, finding extreme values, and summarizing the data -- in general, getting familiar with your raw data before you start to apply a statistical model! In this workshop, we will use dplyr (tidyverse) commands, like group_by() and summarize(), to highlight these important EDA steps.

EDA also includes graphing raw data to assess initial trends. The workshop will also cover different kinds of data visualisations, including box plots, scatterplots with trend lines, and bar plots with the ggplot package. The focus will be on quickly deploying informative graphs and selecting the right geom()s for the data types you have.

No previous knowledge is assumed, just general experience with R (loading packages, reading in data, etc.). If you'd like to polish up your tidyverse skills before joining, check out our previous workshop on data wrangling: https://youtu.be/NRgdTaAfwTo

title: IntroducciÃ³n a Tidymodels. Parte 2: modelos mixtos
description:
Â¡Hola!

Esta segunda parte del taller de introducciÃ³n a Tidymodels estarÃ¡ a cargo de Alejandra Tapia Silva y estarÃ¡ dirigida a personas nuevas en el modelado con efectos mixtos. CubrirÃ¡ aspectos introductorios de este tema esperando que sea un punto de partida para el uso de estos modelos con R y {tidymodels}. No se utilizan fÃ³rmulas matemÃ¡ticas, en un intento de hacerlo amigable e intuitivo y asÃ­ poder dar atenciÃ³n a una audiencia mÃ¡s amplia.

Para aprovechar mejor este taller, es necesario tener algo de experiencia con anÃ¡lisis exploratorio de datos y modelos lineales, de tal manera de poder transitar sin mucho obstÃ¡culo teÃ³rico por cada una de las etapas del modelamiento con efectos mixtos. AdemÃ¡s, es necesario contar con conocimientos iniciales de algunos paquetes del tidyverse (como {readr} y {dplyr}).

REQUERIMIENTOS

AdemÃ¡s de {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, que utilizamos en la primera parte de este taller, es necesario instalar los siguientes paquetes:
\> install\.packages\(c\("broom\.mixed"\,"lme4"\,"lmerTest"\)\)
Luego del taller se dejarÃ¡n referencias para quienes tengan interÃ©s en una explicaciÃ³n mÃ¡s detallada sobre modelos mixtos y {tidymodels}, de tal manera que cuando comiencen a usar estas herramientas con sus propios datos dispongan de mayor informaciÃ³n.

CÃ“DIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estÃ¡s aceptando nuestro cÃ³digo de conducta: https://guide.rladies.org/about/coc/#spanish

Â¡Te esperamos!

R-Ladies

title: Switching between space and time: Spatio-temporal analysis with cubble
description:
Dear all,

Our next meetup will take place **live at TU Wien**. Our speaker is **Sherry Zhang** who is visiting from Australia and will introduce us to the **cubble** package, walking us through how we can work with spatial data and temporal data in R, and how we can more easily combine the two using *cubble*.

**Abstract**: Weather data have a spatial component given by the station coordinates and a temporal component that provides measurements on precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature. This will be a hand-on session to work with weather station data. We will use the package *sf* to work on the spatial side to generate some maps and the package *tsibble* to conduct some exploratory data analysis on the temporal side. One way to communicate space and time information together is through a glyph map where temporal coordinates are transformed into space. We will create the glyph map with the *ggplot* geom: *geom_glyph()*. Lastly, we will experiment with a new data structure, *cubble*, to arrange spatio-temporal data.

Best regards,
Your R-Ladies Vienna Organizing Team

title: TidyTuesday with R-Ladies Philly
description:
[Tidy Tuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is a weekly data project where R enthusiasts across the globe share their plots, analysis, and thoughts about a new data set.
It's a great way to get started with R or really stretch your R skills in a fun way and try something new.

At this interactive event, we will facilitate some analysis and live coding of this weekâ€™s Tidy Tuesday dataset guided by what attendees want to try!

This event is welcome to all. If you are completely new to R, we wonâ€™t be covering installation, set-up, or other introductory topics. However, it should still be a fun event to join and learn by watching.

**This is an online event co-hosted by R-Ladies DC and R-Ladies Philly. Please feel free to RSVP on one or both meetup pages.**

title: Modeling infectious diseases
description:
**R-Ladies NYC & R-Ladies Rome** are coming together for a joint event.

Get ready for an electrifying presentation!

In this talk, we will delve into the fascinating world of modeling diseases with R using both deterministic and Bayesian SIR model methods while exploring the exciting insights that each field has to offer.

At the heart of our discussion is the well-known Sir model, this model can help us understand how an epidemic might unfold and what measures can be taken to prevent its spread.

So, do not miss this fascinating talk about modeling infectious diseases. Whether you are a student of science, a healthcare professional, or simply someone who wants to understand more about how to use R for modeling diseases, this talk promises to be insightful!

**Schedule of the event:**

* Introduction presentation of the Chapters and [R-Ladies Global](https://www.linkedin.com/notifications/?filter=all#) action
* SIR model with R - quick intro assessment (Speaker [Federica Gazzelloni](https://www.linkedin.com/notifications/?filter=all#))
* Bayesian workflow for disease transmission (Speaker [Jacqueline Novik](https://www.linkedin.com/notifications/?filter=all#))
* Q&A session

\-\-\-\-
Si parla di malattie infettive. In questo talk, approfondiremo l'affascinante mondo delle malattie. Utilizzeremo R per il modello di tipo deterministico e bayesiano, e esploreremo le entusiasmanti intuizioni che ogni campo ha da offrire.

Al centro della nostra discussione c'Ã¨ il noto modello Sir, questo modello puÃ² aiutarci a capire come potrebbe evolve un'epidemia, discuteremo su possibili modi di calibrare i modelli, e quali misure possono essere prese per prevenirne la diffusione.

Quindi, non perdere questo meetup! Che tu sia uno studente di scienze, un professionista sanitario o semplicemente qualcuno che vuole capire di piÃ¹ su come usare R per applicare i modelli per le malattie infettive.

title: Crea tu portafolio web para bÃºsquedas de empleo con Quarto y RStudio
description:
**Crea tu portafolio web para bÃºsquedas de empleo y servicios freelance con Quarto y RStudio**

title: R-Ladies @ BSC |  Tools for Climate Forecasting & AI for Cancer Immunotherapy
description:
Join us for an amazing workshop, co-organized with BarcelonaR, at the Barcelona Supercomputing Centre!

**Programme**
*18:30* -> Introduction of R-Ladies Barcelona and BarcelonaR user group.
18:40 -> "Collaborative R tools for Climate Forecast Analysis by HPC" (An-Chi Ho and Eva RifÃ )
19:00 -> "AI in R: PredIG an explainable XGBoost predictor for cancer immunotherapy" (Roc Farriol-Duran)

**"Collaborative R tools for Climate Forecast Analysis by HPC"** (An-Chi and Eva)
A large amount of data is used in the study of climate. This is why the use of HPC is necessary to carry out the analysis and processing of climate data. In addition, multidisciplinary workflows require the use of shared tools that originate collaboration between scientists and engineers. The talk presents some R packages developed within the Computational Earth Sciences group of the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS). It also highlights how collaboration between climate scientists and data engineers using R tools can improve our understanding of climate patterns and lead to better predictions. The use of HPC can speed up calculations and enable the handling of large data sets, making it a valuable tool in climate analysis and prediction.

**"AI in R: PredIG an explainable XGBoost predictor for cancer immunotherapy"** (Roc)
AI in R is (of course) possible. XGBoost is a state-of-the-art algorithm (Kaggle winner, specially working on tabular data) based on gradient boosting and decision trees that is fully implemented in R (R-package: â€œxgboostâ€). Here, we will show an implementation on a biomedical research question: how to predict the immune response against a tumor (and its mutations)?. This case will allow us to focus on a binary classification problem with extreme class imbalance (due to the nature of real patient data) and how (re)tuning XGBoost to deal with imbalance can make it work.

*Language*: English

*Requirements*: There are no specific requirements.

title: Plotting with R
description:
We are finally having Rladies meetups in person again! For this session we will be creating Tidy Tuesday plots together (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday). Tidy Tuesday is an ongoing project by the R4DS Online Learning Community where a new dataset is posted each week aimed at helping learners practice their wrangling and visualization skills.

Donâ€™t know where to start? During the start of the meeting, we will have a short tutorial and write some code together to get your plots started. We also included some resources below to help provide some inspiration!

Come out and meet some R-Ladies from Vancouver and try out some new data visualization skills with us!

Workshop details:
Date and time: April 20 2023, doors at 5:45pm, 6:00pm start

**IMPORTANT**\*\*

1. Please put your full name and confirm that you are over the age of 18 when you sign up. This is a requirement of the venue and we will need to provide that information to them to get access to the appropriate floor.
2. Bring your computer and charger (if needed)
3. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
4. Who is allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

***

General workshop information:

-Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we are all encouraged to learn together.

Software requirements:

* R (Free at https://cran.r-project.org/)
* RStudio (Free at https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/)

Resources:
Data Visualization https://clauswilke.com/dataviz/
Wrangle your data with dplyr - https://allisonhorst.shinyapps.io/dplyr-learnr/

Colour Palettes:
Wes Anderson Colour Palette https://github.com/karthik/wesanderson
Studio Ghibli Colour Palette https://ewenme.github.io/ghibli/

Sci-Fi Themed Colour Palette https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggsci/vignettes/ggsci.html

Fun:
Emoji plots - https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/emojifont/vignettes/emojifont.html

Inspiration:
Collection of best tidy tuesday plots https://www.cedricscherer.com/2019/12/30/best-tidytuesday-2019/
https://twitter.com/hashtag/TidyTuesday?src=hashtag_click

Onsite parking is available on P0, the lowermost level of the building.
Secure parking is available in the underground parkade, accessible from the laneway on the west side of the building. The parking facility will have meters to purchase parking, at the following rates (plus applicable taxes):

See you there!

title: R in the Outdoors
description:
Join us for lightning talks! Presented in-person at UW Medicine in South Lake Union. This will be a hybrid event.

Hope to see you there!

Address:
850 Republican St.
Building C, Room C123
Seattle, WA 98109

title: Basics of data visualization - theory and practice
description:
[Laura Garrison](https://www.laura-garrison.com/) (PhD in Data Visualization from UiB) will teach us a bit of theory behind creating stunning visualizations, while Julia Romanowska will show us how to implement this in {ggplot2}.

If you want to participate in the hands-on part, be sure to bring your laptop with R and RStudio installed, as well as the following R packages:

* tidyverse
* here
* patchwork
* ggiraph

The workshop materials will be made available via GitHub before the session.

**Brief About Laura:**
I use visualization to ask questions and tell stories about data. Earning my PhD in Visualization from the University of Bergen in 2022, my work focuses on visual exploration and communication of information, mainly from the health and life sciences. I am also a professional biomedical artist, meaning I've drawn guts for a living. Prior to my PhD, I worked for six years as an artist and content director in medical education start-ups in Silicon Valley, Chicago, and New York City. I love combining art, science, and technology to help people understand data or concepts, especially in the areas of biology and medicine. More recently, I've become interested in developing visualizations that are more accessible, i.e., usable and understandable, for different segments of the population. Currently, I divide my time as a consultant at Bouvet ASA and at the Mohn Medical Imaging and Visualization Centre (MMIV) at Haukeland Univ. Hospital in Bergen.

title: Cluster analysis in R with Cait Robinson
description:
This talk and workshop will introduce you to k-means cluster analysis using RStudio. K-means clustering groups similar items in the form of clusters. It is a useful approach for identifying patterns in a multi-dimensional dataset. During the session we will run through the fundamentals of the technique in an accessible way. We will also consider how best to visualise the outputs of our clustering. The session will focus on the example of energy inequalities in Greater London, but the technique has a wide range of application areas across different disciplines and sectors. After an introduction to the technique, you will have time to have a go of the clustering yourself. All of the code, and detailed walk throughs, will be provided.

\*\*Please bring a laptop so you can fully participate in the workshop.\*\*

After the workshop, we will have ample time for networking and chat over some snacks and drinks (courtesy of the Software Sustainability Institute).

*Cait is a quantitative human geographer, her research investigates the causes and consequences of different types of spatial inequality, with a particular interest in energy, climate and urban inequalites. She uses spatial, quantitative datasets and methods to understand inequality across multiple scales.*
*â€‹*
*In 2022 she joined the University of Bristol as an Academic Fellow and Proleptic Lecturer in the School of Geographical Sciences. She is currently a [UKRI Future Leaders Fellow](https://news.liverpool.ac.uk/2021/09/08/five-liverpool-researchers-awarded-future-leaders-fellowships/), working on a four year project mapping ambient vulnerabilities in cities.*

title: Meaningful data visualisations in R ggplot2
description:
Welcome to the first R-Ladies Wellington meetup event!

In this event, we will be focusing on the R package ggplot2 for data visualisation. The workshop will cover the basics of the package and how to use it to create meaningful and informative graphics that effectively communicate your data's message.

In addition to the workshop, we will have some time set aside for networking, where you can connect with other R coders and build new connections within the community. We encourage attendees to bring along their laptops and any datasets they would like to work with during the workshop.

We would like to express our gratitude to Nicholson Consulting for generously offering their space to support the establishment of the R-Ladies community in Wellington.

We look forward to seeing you there!

Please note: this event has a capacity limit, and we may not be able to accommodate additional attendees beyond that limit. However, we will be sharing a video recording and slides of the workshop after the event for those who are unable to attend in person.

title: Debugging in R with Shannon Pileggi
description:
**Save the date - Event coming up soon!**
(We are on a roll this year)

Dear R-Ladies SB,
We are excited to announce our upcoming event with the extraordinary [Shannon Pileggi](https://www.pipinghotdata.com/) on ***Debugging***!

Learn how to unlock your programming superpower with debugging techniques! In this workshop, we will review code troubleshooting tips, discuss debugging functions (*traceback()*, *browser()*, *debug()*, *trace()*, and *recover()*), and distinguish between strategies for debugging your own code versus someone elseâ€™s code.

**Event Details**
**When:** Wednesday, April 12, 2023, 5 to 7pm PDT
**Where:** Remote (We will provide a link closer to the day of the event)
**Details:** This will be a hands-on workshop in Posit (RStudio) Cloud. This is a special instance of RStudio that you access through your browser. We will share details on how to log in to Posit Cloud when we send out the Zoom link closer to the event.
**Agenda:** We will open the zoom room at 5pm PST to say hi, mingle and make sure everyone has access to Posit Cloud. The workshop will start at 5:15pm PDT.

**Speaker:** Shannon is an enthusiastic professional educator, data scientist, and statistical consultant. As an R-Ladies Global leadership team member, she advocates for gender diversity in the R community and supports local R-Ladies chapters. She works as a Data Scientist at The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Consortium. In the past, Shannon has contributed to research on parasitic diseases at the CDC, developed curriculum at the Institute for Quantitative Theory and Methods at Emory University, and instructed advanced programming and modeling courses at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo.

title: the Basics of Visualising Map Data in R using ggplot2
description:
**SPEAKER**
Dana Roemling (she/they) is a Ph.D. student in Applied Linguistics at the University of Birmingham. Their research interests are in forensic linguistics, language and law, sociolinguistics, and lavender linguistics. Their PhD focuses on dialect features in authorship profiling. Although they worked in IT before doing their PhD, they only really started programming during their PhD studies. Now they have grown to enjoy R.
You can find Dana on her personal web or on Twitter
https://danaroemling.com/
@danaroemling

**Topic**
This workshop is designed to provide you with the basics of visualising map data in R using ggplot2. The workshop will provide a brief introduction into mapping data, which is useful, for example, in regional dialectology or typology - or generally when your data is regionally distributed. Weâ€™ll focus on creating maps from scratch and mapping linguistic variables using R so that we can visualise and identify patterns in the data.

**PREPARATION**
The R packages we'll need are: maps, rworldmap, sf, tidyverse, dplyr
They can sometimes be tricky to install, so I suggest you try it beforehand.
The data and code we'll work with will be available here: [https://github.com/danaroemling/mapping](https://github.com/danaroemling/mapping)

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The workshop will be held online, starting on 5th April at 16:00 (UK time). Please join us via this Zoom link:
[https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/89852185657?pwd=VWRXRFhkWTVqK0FjOG1ZVm83VzhXUT09](https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/89852185657?pwd=VWRXRFhkWTVqK0FjOG1ZVm83VzhXUT09)

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: Tidy data: Wrangling for statistical analysis in R
description:
We're starting a brand new series walking you through all the steps necessary to prepare, explore, and analyse your data in R!

This first workshop covers the concepts of "tidy data" and data wrangling commands from the tidyverse packages: the essentials for getting your data into the right format for visualisation and model fitting.

This event is suitable for beginners - you should know how to load packages and read data into R. Feel free to take a look at our video that covers these tasks: https://youtu.be/NO6ikdBxSwg

\-\-\-

It's important to us to ensure that R-Ladies Freiburg events are a safe space for anyone of a minority gender, specifically including transgender, gender non-conforming and nonbinary people as well as folks questioning their gender. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: IMPORTANCIA DO R-LADIES PARA O DESENVOLVIMENTO CIENTIFICO E  SOCIAL
description: IMPORTANCIA DO R-LADIES PARA O DESENVOLVIMENTO CIENTIFICO E SOCIAL

title: Creating your Data Science Portfolio
description:
Creating a data science portfolio can help you to develop your skills, and well as showcase them to the wider world. However, getting started on making your portfolio can feel like a huge task. In this talk, I'll discuss how I used #TidyTuesday to gradually build an R portfolio.

We'll run through an example of a #TidyTuesday contribution, including:

* downloading data
* initial data exploration
* creating and styling your plots
* sharing your data visualisations and code

.....and just like that, you have a portfolio!

title: BlgrdR: Make you code more shareable, reusable and reproducible with R packages
description:
Dear R ladies, BelgradeR colleagues are organizing online Meetup on Tuesday.

Details and link:

**Wrap it up: Make you code more shareable, reusable and reproducible with R packages**
**Speaker: Mike Page**
**N.B.** This is an **online event**.
**Abstract**
R packages are the fundamental unit of reproducible R code. In this talk, Mike is going to make a case that everybody writing R code should be thinking about abstracting their work into this format, from stand-alone analyses to Shiny apps. The talk will be grounded in real-world examples from data science work performed at the British Red Cross, discussing the benefits and costs of approaching everything as an R package. The talk will conclude with some concrete advice on how to improve your workflow using an R package structure.
**Bio**
Mike Page is a data scientist on the Strategic Insight and Foresight team at the British Red Cross. Here, he helps to develop a suite of open source tools, such as the Covid-19 Vulnerability Index, to help operational decision making in the charity and the broader voluntary and community sector. Mike is also the author of several R packages, including geographr and mortyr. In his spare time you can find him mountain biking and rock climbing around the Alps.
**More:**

* [https://www.mikejohnpage.com/](https://www.mikejohnpage.com/)
* [https://github.com/humaniverse](https://github.com/humaniverse)

**Event details:**
18:00 BelgradeR :: Mike Page, Make you code more shareable, reusable and reproducible with R packages

title: Boook Club "Machine Learning with R" - Clustering
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with Râ€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell!

Monday March 27, we will talk about pt IV of the book: Clustering! From the book:

In PART III of this book we focused on methods for reducing the dimension of our feature space (p). The remaining chapters concern methods for reducing the dimension of our observation space (n); these methods are commonly referred to as *clustering*. *K*-means clustering is one of the most commonly used clustering algorithms for partitioning observations into a set of k groups (i.e. k clusters), where k is pre-specified by the analyst. *k*-means, like other clustering algorithms, tries to classify observations into mutually exclusive groups (or clusters), such that observations within the same cluster are as similar as possible (i.e., high intra-class similarity), whereas observations from different clusters are as dissimilar as possible (i.e., low inter-class similarity). In *k*-means clustering, each cluster is represented by its center (i.e, centroid) which corresponds to the mean of the observation values assigned to the cluster. The procedure used to find these clusters is similar to the *k*-nearest neighbor (KNN) algorithm discussed in Chapter [8](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/knn.html#knn); albeit, without the need to predict an average response value.

These chapters (20-22) will be presented by one of the organizers of R Ladies Den Bosch: Martine.

The attentive reader might notice that we skipped part III of the book: dimension reduction. This part contains chapter 17 Principal Components Analysis, 18 Generalised Low Rank models, and 19 Autoencoders. If you are looking for a fun little challenge and would like to present one or more of these chapters, please send us a message!

title: IntroducciÃ³n a Tidymodels. Parte 1: modelos lineales
description:
Â¡Hola!

Â¡Volvimos!

Si tienes un manejo bÃ¡sico de R y tidyverse, y quieres comenzar a generar modelos predictivos de regresiÃ³n o clasificaciÃ³n, este taller es para ti. Veremos las funciones principales del paquete tidymodels y desarrollaremos un modelo lineal de regresiÃ³n. Esta sesiÃ³n estarÃ¡ a cargo de Sara Acevedo, Doctora en Ciencias de la IngenierÃ­a.

REQUERIMIENTOS

Antes del taller es necesario que instales los paquetes {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, junto con sus dependencias:
\> install\.packages\(c\("tidyverse"\, "tidymodels"\)\, dependencies = TRUE\)
Asimismo, es necesario tener los paquetes {remotes} y {ggsignif}, junto con sus dependencias:
\> install\.packages\(c\("remotes"\, "ggsignif"\)\, dependencies = TRUE\)
AdemÃ¡s, debes instalar desde GitHub los paquete {datos} y {corrr} (ojo que tienes que tener instalado el paquete {remotes} para que funcionen las siguientes lÃ­neas de cÃ³digo):
\> remotes::install_github\("cienciadedatos/datos"\)
\> remotes::install_github\("tidymodels/corrr"\)

title: Women in Community International Womenâ€™s Day
description:
Join us for a remarkable event, "Women in Community International Women's Day" and celebrate the tremendous achievements of women around the world! On March 25, 2023, we are gathering an exceptional group of inspiring women, who have made an outstanding contribution to their respective fields within the community. This event is all about celebrating diversity, inclusion, and women's empowerment.
Our panelists will share their stories of breaking down barriers and fighting for equality and justice. Our audience can expect to hear stories of bravery, resilience, and strength, and learn about the challenges women face in various aspects of community building.
This event is perfect for anyone who is passionate about women's rights, gender equality, and making the world a better place for all. Expect to leave feeling inspired, empowered, and equipped with the tools and knowledge to drive change in your own community.
Don't miss this fantastic opportunity to celebrate International Women's Day with some of the most incredible women you'll ever meet.

For questions, send an email to lagos@rladies.org

title: Introduction to NLP with R
description:
This light introduction to working with unstructured text data while leveraging Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques will provide a glance of the underlying approach, cover tips on how to get started and structure your project and show examples on how to transform text into usable insights.
This presentation is suitable for novice to intermediate practitioners who want to learn more about this topic. No prior knowledge is required, and anyone interested is encouraged to attend.
Use passcode 907450 to join the meeting
