description:
This workshop is free and open to all. It is for beginners with no previous experience and will be taught in two sessions from 5:00 - 7:00 pm on Thursdays in Room 206 of Edmon Low Library. See the QR code above to register.

March 23rd - Basic coding and graphing
March 30th - Basic analysis

Please share with students, especially undergraduates.

title: Custom colour scales for {ggplot2}
description:
For the second dataviz lunchtime meetup, Nicola Rennie will talk about colours.

Abstract:
There are many colour palette packages in R that are compatible with {ggplot2}, but sometimes you might want to use your own choice of colours. For example, you might want them to match company or university branding guidelines. In this talk, I'll show you how to make your own custom colour scale functions to add your own colours to {ggplot2} graphics â€“ no more copying and pasting \`scale_colour_manual()\`!

Agenda:
12 pm GMT Talk
12.20 pm GMT Q&A with the speaker
12.45 pm GMT End of the meetup

Please be aware that the talk will be at 12 pm UK time. Check your time zone before registering.

title: [ONLINE] R-Ladies RTP x SB meetup: #tidytuesday Work Group (on a Wednesday)
description:
Come join your fellow R users in R-Ladies RTP and R-Ladies Santa Barbara in a joint meet up exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

All events are intended for minoritized genders as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend as guests and must be accompanied by the member who invited them. This group was created so that women, non-binary, gender non-conforming, and minoritized folks have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

At this event, we'll check out the LTERdataSampler R package. Specifically, this R package contains a number of data sets from Long-term Ecological Research (LTER) sites. You can read more about it here:[ ](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2022/2022-06-07)[https://lter.github.io/lterdatasampler/index.html](https://lter.github.io/lterdatasampler/index.html).

**Agenda (all times in ET):**
6:30 - 6:45 pm Meet & Greet
6:45 - 7:45 pm #tidytuesday breakout rooms
7:45 - 8:00 pm Discussion

**What is #tidytuesday?**
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach! For more information on #tidytuesday, check out [the main repository page](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

**Who is this for?**
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world. This meetup is organized in collaboration with R-Ladies Santa Barbara.

**What should I bring?**
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

**Where will it take place?**
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

title: What's new in the tidyverse
description:
If you're an R user, chances are you've heard of the tidyverse - a suite of packages that's revolutionized data wrangling, visualization, and analysis. And if you've been following the [tidyverse blog](https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/), you'll know there's been a veritable flood of new functions and feature releases lately.

In this talk, we'll give you the inside scoop on all the latest and greatest updates to the tidyverse. From a new family of string-separating functions to a bunch of new joins, we'll show you how this cutting-edge universe of packages can make your life as a data scientist easier, more efficient, and more intuitive. So buckle up and get ready to explore what's new in the tidyverse!

\-\-\-
Se sei un utente R, Ã¨ probabile che tu abbia sentito parlare di tidyverse, un insieme di pacchetti che ha rivoluzionato la gestione, la visualizzazione e l'analisi dei dati. E se hai seguito il blog tidyverse, saprai che ultimamente c'Ã¨ stata una vera e propria ondata di nuove funzioni e nuove funzionalitÃ .

In questo talk, scorirai in anteprima su tutti gli ultimi e i migliori aggiornamenti del pacchetto tidyverse. Da una nuova famiglia di funzioni di separazione delle stringhe a una serie di nuovi join, ti mostreremo come questo universo di pacchetti all'avanguardia puÃ² rendere la tua vita da data scientist piÃ¹ semplice, piÃ¹ efficiente e piÃ¹ intuitiva. Quindi allaccia le cinture e preparati a esplorare le novitÃ  in tidyverse!
\-\-\-

title: Data Science Job Search and Career Panel (RSVP in Event Description)
description:
On the hunt for a new job? Given the current labor market, R-Ladies is hosting a panel featuring recruiters and data science team leaders to provide unique insight in to the job application and interview process.

**\*\*\*IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT RSVPs\*\*\***
Please RSVP using the following [google form](https://forms.gle/74FjvxnTBqJJi42aA) so we can reach out to you about zoom link details closer to the event date.

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Event Timeline
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

* **7:00pm - 7:10pm: event introduction and panelist introductions**
* **7:10pm - 7:45pm: 35 minutes of prepared questions**
* **7:45pm - 8:00pm 15 minutes of audience questions**

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
Speakers
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
***Sherry Shenker*** *is a data science manager at Flatiron Health, where she helps build products to generate insights from data on real-world cancer patients. She previously worked as an applied data scientist at Civis Analytics, and graduated with a B.A. in Economics from the University of Chicago. She loves applying data science skills in new problem areas, spending as much time as possible outside, and cooking for friends and family.*

***Jaime Engle*** *started her career doing full desk tech recruiting at two different staffing agencies before going in house to* *Uptake. She was the 30th employee at Uptake and the company grew to over 850 employees and reached a $1B unicorn valuation during her three-year tenure. Then she joined a data science consulting firm- Civis Analytics for 3.5 years where she led the talent function. After that, she spent a few months at Salesforce, and then returned to the startup world at Balto, an* *AI call assist SaaS company. In January of 2023, Jaime joined Lantern Partners- a 20 year old executive search firm where she recruits C-level executives for growth stage tech companies*.

***Lauren Vecchio*** *is a holistic Talent Acquisition and Development practitioner, Lauren is currently a Learning & Development Program Implementation Manager at marketing tech startup, Wunderkind. She acts as a catalyst for employees to develop professionally, spring boarding their careers and meeting their fullest potential. Prior to that, Lauren held several talent acquisition roles where she bridged the gap between top tech talent and high-growth companies across the martech, ecommerce, fintech, and advertising industries. In her free time, you can catch her snapping photos, nerding out about personality typing, or drinking a grenadine-filled dirty shirley.*
\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-
R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): [https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct)
For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: Exploratory visualization of spatial data  with {mapview}
description:

12 pm GMT Talk

12.40 pm GMT Conclusion

Description
R has several great packages for creating maps, but if you're looking for speed and ease, it's hard to beat mapview. Sharon will demo how little code you need to create an interactive map to visualize, explore, and share spatial data.

title: an introduction to Bayesian statistics in R.
description:
**SPEAKER**
**Due to the train strike, today's talk is delayed to 4:45 pm. we are sorry!!!**
Dr. Mahmoud Elsherif will lead this online workshop.
Currently, Mahmoud is a researcher associate in Psychology at the University of Birmingham. He received the Leverhulme early career grant and will move to the University of Leicester to investigate linguistic predictions in younger and older adults.
Mahmoud has been using R since his Ph.D. for data analysis, modeling, and visualization.
To follow him online:
Twitter: https://twitter.com/MamsMandrill
He has many exciting and high-quality publications:
Researchgate: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mahmoud-Elsherif-2

**WORKSHOP OVERVIEW**
Frequentists dominated statistical practice for many years. However,
bayesian data analysis is increasingly becoming the tool of choice for many data-analysis problems. Mahmoud will present an introduction to Bayesian statistics in R.

**PREPARATION AND RESOURCES**
No, at this moment.

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The event will be held online and will start at 16:45 (GMT), 16th March 2023
Please join us via this Zoom link:
[https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/87167989030?pwd=WmpzQmw3UmwxTUhISkJlNmpRWWFwQT09](https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/87167989030?pwd=WmpzQmw3UmwxTUhISkJlNmpRWWFwQT09)

**CODE OF CONDUCT**
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: R-Ladies Boulder #27: Integrating R & Google Workspaces w/ Jade Yonehiro
description:
"As data analysts, we often collaborate with colleagues on analyses and data presentations who do not have R or other statistical programming skill sets. These collaborations can be frustrating for both the analyst and non-analyst, with the analyst needing to make and remake tables or visuals and the non-analyst lacking the autonomy to tweak or explore data themselves. One open access and open source based solution is to develop workflows between R and more accessible programs such as Excel or Google Sheets. The googlesheets4 package provides analysts a linking tool so they can leverage the power of R for data processing and visualization while empowering non-analysts with a user-friendly environment for collaboration."

Zoom link for remote attendees: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/85471235979?pwd=a3FBRWpubysxcDYzS1FvZlhEWVlHZz09

title: An Introduction to Spark with R
description:
With information growing at exponential rates, itâ€™s no surprise that historians are referring to this period of history as the Information Age. The increasing speed at which data is being collected has created new opportunities and is certainly poised to create even more.
Apache Spark been a leading tool that is democratizing our ability to process large datasets, there comes `sparklyr`, a project merging R and Spark into a powerful tool that is easily accessible to all R users.
During this webinar, Edgar would take us through:

* basic understanding of Apache Spark,
* installing the sparklyr package in rstudio,
* reading data with sparklyr package, and finally
* a simple example of modeling your data

We hope to have you join us.

title: Efficient dependency management with {renv}
description:
The [{renv} package](https://rstudio.github.io/renv/articles/renv.html) can help us keep track of all the packages we're using in a specific project and create backups or freeze package versions for later use. This makes sharing and re-running code easier. Let's dive into how we can incorporate this into our projects!

This is the first meeting in a series about {renv} - [Julia Romanowska](https://www.uib.no/en/persons/Julia.Romanowska) will give us a quick intro into the package, with some examples. Then, we can discuss, mingle, and set up dates for the next meetings.

**NOTE:** the room is booked for 2 hours, but you can come and leave whenever you want.

The series is co-organized by TÃ¼rkÃ¼ler Ã–zgÃ¼mÃ¼s and Jessica Louise Ray.

title: Winter Social
description:
Let's gather for some fun in this chilly weather - join us at the upcoming R-Ladies Seattle winter social! It's the perfect opportunity to meet other R-Ladies and bond over your shared love for R programming.

We're meeting at the TeKu Tavern, a cozy bar that boasts a wide variety of global brews and non-alcoholic beverages. Show off your spiRit by collecting awesome hex stickers and participating in our R-themed raffle.

Please note that the event is for R-Ladies members only. It is limited to 24 RSVPs due to space constraints, so please update your response if your plans change.

We can't wait to see you and celebrate the winter season together!

title: Dealing with spatial data using R with Alessia Calafiore
description:
**R-Ladies Edinburgh are back with our first in-person event of 2023!**

In this hands-on workshop we are going to play with some spatial data to learn about basic spatial operations and map making with R. To do this, we will leverage three great R packages, {sf}, {ggplot2} and {leaflet}. By the end of the workshop, you will be able to load, manipulate and visualise spatial data with beautiful maps. This will be an introductory workshop and no previous knowledge of spatial analysis or mapping is required.

\*\*Please bring a laptop so you can fully participate in the workshop.\*\*

After the workshop, we will have ample time for networking and chat over some snacks and drinks (courtesy of the Software Sustainability Institute).

*Alessia is a Lecturer in Sustainability and Urban Data Science at the Edinburgh Future Institute and the Edinburgh School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture of the University of Edinburgh. Prior to this, she was a postdoctoral research associate at the Geographic Data Science Lab of the University of Liverpool.*
*Alessia's research sits at the intersection of Urban Planning, Geography and Computer Science and she interested in developing new spatially informed computational methods to better understand the mutual relationship between human behaviours and their urban contexts. Her current substantive focus concerns how we can equitability manage Net Zero transitions within cities.*

description:

Join us for an exciting **panel discussion** featuring some very interesting **guests**
\- Andrea Schnell \(Statistisches Amt Kanton ZÃ¼rich\)

title: Book Club "Machine Learning with R" - Interpretable Machine Learning
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with Râ€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell!

Monday March 6, we will talk about interpretable machine learning
From the book:

In the previous chapters you learned how to train several different forms of advanced ML models. Often, these models are considered â€œblack boxesâ€ due to their complex inner-workings. However, because of their complexity, they are typically more accurate for predicting nonlinear, faint, or rare phenomena. Unfortunately, more accuracy often comes at the expense of interpretability, and interpretability is crucial for business adoption, model documentation, regulatory oversight, and human acceptance and trust. Luckily, several advancements have been made to aid in interpreting ML models over the years and this chapter demonstrates how you can use them to extract important insights.
This chapter will be presented by one of the authors of the book: Brandon Greenwell!

title: [Online] Bayesian Data Analysis with BRMS
description:

How to Join the Webinar

title: Tidy Tuesday
description:
â¤ï¸ **R-Ladies Helsinki is back!** â¤ï¸

We are running our first "Tidy Tuesday" event.

Bring your laptops and your curious mind, and let's start analyzing some fun data set together.

We will have mentors to help you on the way of data mingling and creating beautiful charts. If you are a beginner in R, don't be shy! We are having an open-level event. **Everyone is welcome!**

Save your spot and make sure you RSVP before the **26th of February**. Please send us your full name, we'll prepare name tags.

Prerequisites are below if you want to code by yourself during the event:

* R and RStudio installed on your machine:

\- https://cran\.r\-project\.org/bin/
\- https://posit\.co/download/rstudio\-desktop/

* Packages tidyverse, more specifically ggplot2 and dplyr installed

\- If you want to install before you arrive run this code piece *install.packages('tidyverse')*

* We will help you on the way to installation if you don't feel like doing it by yourselves.

See you soon! â¤ï¸

title: Blog Writing Workshop
description:
Do you want to start a technical blog? Curious about how to publish your blog? Do you have blog ideas but want to get feedback? Well then this is the Meetup for you!

We will work in small groups to workshop your blog ideas. Don't have any ideas yet? No problem! Here are a few topics that would make for a good blog post:

* Share your experience of learning a new programming language
* Write about your favorite packages or functions
* Talk about a recent data set or project you worked on

How do you get your blog out there?! **R-Ladies Rome is hosting a Meetup about Quarto**, which can be used to publish blogs! [Join R-Ladies Rome on Monday February 13th at 1:00 pm EST](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-rome/events/290673316/) to learn more about all the cool things Quarto can do.

Can't make it? No problem! We will share resources about Quarto during our Meetup. And R-Ladies NYC can host your blog post on our [website](https://www.rladiesnyc.org/)! Email us at nyc@rladies.org if you are interested in utilizing our blog.

This event will be hosted over Zoom; the link will be available on this page the morning of the event, and the passcode will be emailed to you. **Fill out this form ([https://forms.gle/RHgWsCo8FqnZyQgu7](https://forms.gle/RHgWsCo8FqnZyQgu7)) if you are interested in attending this Blog Writing Workshop**, to ensure you receive the Zoom information the day of the event.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending): [https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct)

For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: Careers in Public Health - IN PERSON REGISTRATION ON EVENTBRITE
description:
**REGISTER IN PERSON ATTENDANCE ON EVENTBRITE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/navigating-public-health-careers-tickets-523492459037**

Hi everyone,

Hï»¿ave you ever thought about what a career in public health could look like and how you get there?

Our February event will showcase a panel of experts sharing the different journeys that brought them to their current roles in public health so as to share with young or/and aspiring epidemiologists/statisticians/lab scientists etc.. what it takes to build a career in this sector and what are the tasks and roles and the different types of careers that one one can build.

This event is co-hosted between R-Ladies Melbourne and Women in Bioinformatics (https://twitter.com/bioinfowomen), a group founded in 2021 by Dr. Nikeisha Caruana that aims at bringing together women and minorities within the Australia bioinformatics community.

The doors will open at 5.30pm with pizza, drinks and networking.
The presentations part of the event will start at 6pm with the speaker's career journey introductions and it will be followed by a panel discussion.

**This is a hybrid event and the zoom meeting passcode will be available on the night of the event.**
**Register your in-person attendance here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/navigating-public-health-careers-tickets-523492459037**

The doors will open at 5.30pm with pizza, drinks and networking.
The presentations part of the event will start at 6pm with the speaker's career journey introductions and it will be followed by a panel discussion.

**Speakers**

**Steph Main (she/her)**
Steph is an applied epidemiologist and global health and development practitioner and researcher. She is currently working at the Melbourne North Eastern Public Health Unit, with a focus on communicable disease prevention, promotion and protection. She trained through Australiaâ€™s accredited Field Epidemiology Training Program at the Australian National University. Her recent work has included COVID-19 outbreak response; communicable disease surveillance and outbreak management in Melbourne; Tuberculosis research and public health programming in Papua New Guinea and Indonesia; and observational and implementation research.

**Danielle Ingle (she/her)**
Dr Danielle Ingle joined the Department of Microbiology and Immunology at the University of Melbourne in late 2020 as an NHMRC Emerging Leadership Fellow. This fellowship will integrate microbial genomics with population modelling, antimicrobial resistance data and epidemiology of enteric bacterial pathogens that represent significant threats to public health. Danielle completed her PhD at the University of Melbourne in 2017. She then moved to the Australian National University as a Research Fellow investigating the evolution and epidemiology of multidrug resistant enteric bacteria.

**Daniella Hock (she/her)**
Dr Daniella Hock is a Research Fellow in clinical proteomics at the University of Melbourne. During her career, she has worked in both industry and research in Australia and Brazil. Her current work focuses on translating proteomics into a clinical test to improve the genetic diagnosis of rare diseases as about half of the patients remain undiagnosed, some of them for years.

Looking forward to seeing you all!

R-Ladies Melbourne and Women in Bioinformatics

title: Beautifully annotated: enhancing your ggplots with text
description:
We are pleased to start this first data visualisation's series of lunch with R-Ladies.

Programme:
12 pm Talk
12:20 pm Q&A
12.40 Conclusion

Description:
Applying design principles to the text in our graphs, and making text an integral part of the visualisation, can make all the difference between a busy plot and a plot which communicates a clear story.

In this session, we will explore:
â€” how to be less dependent on annotations (I knowâ€¦ trust me!)

â€” how to use colours and fonts to draw attention to key elements in annotations

â€” how to format text on the fly to change fonts, colours, alignments, and text sizes using \`{ggtext}\`

â€” how to add arrows to your plots to highlight key data points or important patterns

â€” a few useful packages and ggplot tricks when it comes to annotations

Attendees are welcome to bring along one of their own plots to discuss during the Q&A session for some live feedback.

title: Welcome to R-Ladies Halifax! Introductory Meeting
description:
**Welcome to R-Ladies!**

We are happy to announce the first meeting of R-Ladies Halifax!

This will be a very informal first meeting where we will discuss what you can expect from the chapter. We will have some examples of what R-Ladies looks like in other areas and hopefully find format and content that fits the needs and interests of our Halifax audience.

This will be a great opportunity to connect with other local R users. Please bring any ideas and questions!

We will have a fun tidbit to share as well, how to customize your R-Studio theme to make your workspace as clean or colourful as you like!

title: Regular Expressions and Working with Text Strings
description:
Workshop description:

In R, strings are used for storing text. Most of the data that we work with contains strings, either in object or file names or as values in data frames or other tabular formats. Regular expressions are specially encoded strings of characters that match patterns in other strings. Being able to write regular expressions is an underutilized, valuable skill that can save us time and lines of code when we need to match, extract, or transform text by matching words, characters, and patterns. If a text pattern can be described verbally, we can most likely write a regular expression to match it. For example, we can use regular expressions to match dates, email addresses, strings that start or end with a particular character, etc. This talk will cover the building blocks of regular expressions and how we can use them in R to work with strings, focusing on packages built specifically for string manipulation. This talk is meant to introduce regex to those without prior knowledge and provide a boost for people already familiar.

Link will be posted closer to the event.

title: Add JavaScript data viz to your data science toolkit with Observable Plot
description:
Hi R-Ladies SB!

We are thrilled to welcome Allison Horst & Ananya Roy for our first ever ***JavaScript*** lesson using Observable Plot -- this hands-on workshop-style event may be a slight departure from our R-based meetups in the past, but fear not -- you can expect to see hints of {ggplot2}'s influence in this new-to-us tool!

Please see Allison & Ananya's event description below for more details, and note that this is a **virtual-only event** (Zoom link available upon RSVP).

Be sure to fill out [this fun survey](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScspHfdtwddLsVhJEEywUEIXE7CM6Zt7qsVn8kRVgdvxGZb0g/viewform?usp=send_form) (seriously, it's fun and had us laughing through it all) by Wednesday 2/15 @ 5pm PT so that we have a rad dataset to explore during the workshop!

See you there!

\~ Sam, An, Danielle, & Camila

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

**Description:** We're increasingly seeing different languages and tools combined in computational notebooks. For example, Quarto makes it possible to add Observable JavaScript to .qmd documents, creating exciting opportunities to include custom interactive data visualizations for the web alongside your R code and analyses. How can you get started with data visualization in JavaScript?

In this session, we'll introduce [Observable Plot](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot) \- a JavaScript package with a goal of getting you to "a meaningful visualization quickly\." In particular\, we'll highlight how your grammar of graphics and ggplot2 knowledge maps closely onto Plot code\, and explore how Observable Inputs get you quickly from static to interactive web\-ready visualizations\.

**Beforehand:** We'll be working in Observable notebooks. If you want to save your work from this session, you can create a free account at [observablehq.com](http://observablehq.com). Or, you can follow along and make changes to our shared notebook without creating an account to test it out (in that case, your changes just won't get saved).

**Pre-meetup fun survey:**

We want to explore some data that feels relevant. *Can you help us out?* We've made this [fun little survey](https://forms.gle/LxFupn6wM7KBcqrH6) to build a play dataset for use during the session. Thank you for filling it out by **5pm PT on Wednesday 2/15!**

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ - Chp 15 Stacked Models
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell! Monday February 20, we will talk about stacked models.

From the book:
***Stacking*** involves training a new learning algorithm to combine the predictions of several base learners. First, the base learners are trained using the available training data, then a combiner or meta algorithm, called the *super learner*, is trained to make a final prediction based on the predictions of the base learners.

This chapter will be presented by one of our community members: Ece. Ece Ozler, is from Turkey. She has a graduate degree in Economics from the Koc University in Turkey and a master's in Finance from the Netherlands. She has lived in the Netherlands for almost six years now. She works for an analytics company, FI Analytics, in the banking sector. She uses R and ML to build credit scoring models; C# to build apps that use the prediction models made in R.

**This boook club:**
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (definitely more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see [https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML](https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML).

title: Modelo de RegresiÃ³n con Datos de Panel
description:
Comenzamos nuestros meetup en este mes de febrero y nos complace tener como ponente a una gran R-Lady: Luisa Ames, quien es Licenciada en EstadÃ­stica por la UNMSM y es Magister en EconomÃ­a en la Especialidad de Finanzas y Mercado de Capitales por la PUCP. Tiene experiencia en el Sector Privado y PÃºblico, actualmente es Consultora en ciencia de datos BID en la SUNAT. Anteriormente fue consultora de estadÃ­stica y econometrÃ­a en el MEF y ha sido especialista en analÃ­tica de Datos en el sector privado. Adicionalmente, Luisa es coautora del paper economÃ©trico: Impacto de la confianza empresarial en la demanda de crÃ©dito en el PerÃº por la revista de AnÃ¡lisis EconÃ³mico de octubre 2022 por la Universidad Alberto Hurtado de Chile.

**â€¢ Lo que haremos:**
Luisa, a travÃ©s de un taller prÃ¡ctico, nos enseÃ±arÃ¡ a realizar Modelos de RegresiÃ³n con datos de panel.

La regresiÃ³n de panel es un mÃ©todo de modelizaciÃ³n adaptado a los datos de panel, tambiÃ©n llamados datos longitudinales o transversales. Se usa ampliamente en problemas donde interesa analizar el comportamiento de unidades estadÃ­sticas (es decir, unidades de panel) a lo largo del tiempo.

Sin embargo, existen situaciones en las cuales es posible diseÃ±ar modelos donde se utilice la combinaciÃ³n de ambos tipos de datos, que se obtienen a partir del seguimiento a las mismas unidades de corte transversal a lo largo del tiempo.

Varias son las ventajas de los datos de panel, como lo plantean (gujarati y Porter, 2010); una de ellas es que permiten estudiar la heterogeneidad inobservable que se presenta entre las unidades (empresas, individuos, paÃ­ses, ciudades, regiones, etc.). Al combinar las series de tiempo con las observaciones de corte transversal, el nÃºmero de observaciones se incrementa significativamente, disminuyendo asÃ­ la posible presencia de multicolinealidad. De esta manera se facilita estudiar la dinÃ¡mica que presentan a lo largo del tiempo dichas unidades. En resumen, los datos de panel enriquecen el anÃ¡lisis empÃ­rico, que no serÃ­a posible con datos solo de corte transversal o solo de series de tiempo. Los datos de panel pueden ser balanceados, es decir, cuando se tiene informaciÃ³n completa para todas las unidades, en caso contrario, el dato de panel es no balanceado.

**â€¢ Requisitos:**
\- AsegÃºrate de tener instalado Zoom\.
\- Tener instalado R y RStudio \(de preferencia la versiÃ³n mÃ¡s actualizada\)\.
\- Paquetes que usaremos: Ecdat\, gplots\, stargazer\, plm\, tseries\, lmtest

***IMPORTANTE***
Para participar, dale "AsistirÃ©" en este evento.
Por razones de seguridad no compartiremos el link para ingresar a Zoom de manera pÃºblica. DÃ­as antes del evento estaremos enviando un correo con el link de zoom a sus correos de meetup.

**â€¢ Pregunta frecuente:**
P: Â¿Los chicos son bienvenidos a las reuniones de R-Ladies Lima?
R: SÃ­, los chicos son bienvenidos a cualquiera de nuestros eventos. Puedes revisar nuestro cÃ³digo de conducta global aquÃ­: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: AutoML in R & Python Using H2O
description:
PyLadies and R-Ladies are hosting another event together! We will dive into the logic of AutoML (automatic machine learning) and learn from Erin how we can use the H2O framework in both Python and R ğŸš€ We are happy to collaborate with R-Ladies Cologne (https://www.meetup.com/rladies-cologne/), and Pyladies Paris (https://www.meetup.com/pyladiesparis/) to organize this meetup. We are so excited to be hosting Erin LeDell!

If youâ€™re up for joining us, RSVP here on our Meetup group.

title: AutoML in R & Python using H2O
description:
PyLadies and R-Ladies are hosting another event together! We will dive into the logic of AutoML (automatic machine learning) and learn from Erin how we can use the H2O framework in both Python and R ğŸš€

**âœ¨AutoML in R & Python using H2O âœ¨**
The focus of this presentation is scalable and automatic machine learning using the H2O machine learning platform in R and Python. H2O is an open source, distributed machine learning platform is designed to scale to very large datasets that may not fit into RAM on a single machine. We will provide a brief overview of the field of Automatic Machine Learning, followed by a detailed look inside H2Oâ€™s AutoML algorithm. H2O AutoML provides an easy-to-use interface which automates data pre-processing, training and tuning a large selection of candidate models (including multiple stacked ensemble models for superior model performance), and due to the distributed nature of the H2O platform, H2O AutoML can scale to very large datasets. The result of the AutoML run is a â€œleaderboardâ€ of H2O models which can be explained using the H2O Explainability interface and easily exported for use in production.

If youâ€™re up for joining us, RSVP here. We will share all access details for our virtual event beforehand.

To stay up-to-date with our future events, make sure to also follow us on Twitter ([@PyLadiesParis](https://twitter.com/pyladiesparis?s=21&t=b9quKIe_jXWq3JxlGzB3Kw), [@RLadies_Cologne](https://twitter.com/rladies_cologne), and [@RLadiesParis](https://twitter.com/RLadiesParis)) ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

Weâ€™re very much looking forward to seeing many of you! â˜ºï¸

title: TidyTuesday with R-Ladies Philly & Philly RUG
description:
[Tidy Tuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is a weekly data project where R enthusiasts across the globe share their plots, analysis, and thoughts about a new data set.

It's a great way to get started with R or really stretch your R skills in a fun way and try something new.

At this interactive event, we will facilitate some analysis and live coding of this weekâ€™s tidy tuesday dataset guided by what attendees want to try! You will have a chance to win an exclusive R-related prize if you share a plot, table, or piece of code!

This event is welcome to all. If you are completely new to R, we wonâ€™t be covering installation, set-up, or other introductory topics. However, it should still be a fun event to join and learn by watching.

This is an online event co-hosted by R-Ladies Philly and Philly RUG! Please feel free to RSVP on one or both meetup pages.

title: Introduction to Quarto
description:
In this meetup, Mine will introduce you to Quarto -- an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that unifies and extends the R Markdown ecosystem. Through discussion and live demos, she will share how she uses Quarto for authoring, teaching, and collaborating. In addition, she will also give us a glimpse into the Hello Quarto talk for rstudio::conf(2022), which she co-presented with Julia Stewart Lowndes. You can find that talk at [https://youtu.be/p7Hxu4coDl8](https://youtu.be/p7Hxu4coDl8).


title: Building a career as a Jill of all trades
description: **Abstract**: After finishing my biostats PhD 8 years ago, I started working as a machine learning engineer in the tech industry, and am now working my 4th startup job. While startups and academia do have a lot in common, startups force you to generalize (develop breadth) while other career tracks reward specialization (depth). I'll share a bit about how I've thought about building a fulfilling career as a generalist and how common themes between different application areas really make that possible!

title: Re-Launch Event R-Ladies & BarcelonaR |  R for Geospatial Data Sience
description:
R-Ladies Barcelona is back! And for this re-launch event we are joining forces with the BarcelonaR user group! Join us for an amazing workshop, a fun group dynamic and a networking session over some drinks!

**Programme**
*18:30* -> Introduction of **R-Ladies Barcelona** and **BarcelonaR** user group. We're back!
18:45 -> "R for Geospatial Data Sience" by Paula Moraga PhD
20:00 -> Group dynamic & networking over some drinks!

**R for Geospatial Data Science**
Geospatial health data are essential to inform public health and policy. These data can be used to quantify disease burden, understand geographic and temporal patterns, identify risk factors and measure inequalities. In this tutorial, I will give an overview of statistical methods and R packages for geospatial data analysis and health surveillance. I will demonstrate how to develop spatial models using R-INLA package. I will also show how to create interactive data visualizations and maps, and introduce presentation options such as flexdashboards and Shiny web applications that facilitate the communication of insights to collaborators and policy makers. The tutorial materials are based on the book "Geospatial Health Data: Modeling and Visualization with R-INLA and Shiny" by Paula Moraga (2019, Chapman & Hall/CRC Biostatistics Series) which is freely available at [https://paula-moraga.github.io/book-geospatial/â€¦](https://t.co/Ze22PuuiJB)
*Language*: English
*Requirements*: Participants should bring their laptops with R and RStudio installed. They should also install the following R packages: install.packages(c("sf, "sp", "spdep", "raster", "rgdal", "rgeos", "ggplot2", "leaflet", "dplyr", "SpatialEpi")) install.packages("INLA", repos = "[https://inla.r-inla-download.org/R/stable](https://t.co/QgtPyEY0x4)", dep = TRUE)

venues.name: PRBB Parc de Recerca BiomÃ¨dica de Barcelona

title: [ONLINE] Accessing Census Data in R through APIs
description:
**What will we cover in this event?**
This talk will give an overview of Census APIs available and how to find out which surveys have data available through the Census API. Brief examples will be given on how to use the **censusapi** R package which can access any data in the API. The **tidycensus** R package specifically can access ACS tables, ACS microdata, Decennial tables, PEP tables, and ACS migration flow data. This tutorial will give examples of how to find relevant variables from ACS tables or decennial data using the **tidycensus** package. Examples of getting the data will be provided and how to easily make maps of the data.

**About the Speaker**
Dr. Stephanie Zimmer is a survey statistician who earned her BS in Statistics at NC State and PhD in Statistics at Iowa State. She has been an R user since 2009. Her work at RTI International includes several domains from criminal justice to social science to public health. She works on sampling design, survey weighting, and analysis. She is currently working on a book with Rebecca Powell and Isabella Velasquez on **Tidy Survey Analysis in R**.

**Agenda**
6:30pm - 6:40pm - Introductions
6:40pm - 7:40pm - Tutorial
7:40pm - 8:00pm - Wrap up

**Who is this event for?**
This meetup is for beginners and advanced R programmers alike.

**What should I bring?**
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the internet capabilities to run Zoom and your favorite web browser.

If you're interested in following along with the tutorial, we recommend that you do the following **before the event**. First, install the latest version of R (download that [here](https://cran.r-project.org/)). Second, install the latest version of RStudio Desktop (download that [here](https://posit.co/downloads/)). Last but not least, please install the following R packages: **tidyverse**, **tidycensus**, and **censusapi**. If you have any questions about software and package installation, please contact the event organizer at least 48 hours (or earlier) **before the event**.

**How do I join the event?**
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

**Event Organizer Contact Information**
Please contact Sheila at sheila@rladies.org at least 48 hours (or earlier) **before the event**, if you have any questions.

**A Note About R-Ladies RTP Events**
All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

title: Machine learning operations with vetiver
description:
Many data scientists understand what goes into training a machine learning or statistical model, but creating a strategy to deploy and maintain that model can be daunting. In this meetup, learn what Machine learning operations (MLOps) is, what principles can be used to create a practical MLOps strategy, and what kinds of tasks and components are involved. See how to get started with vetiver, a framework for MLOps tasks in R (and Python!) that provides fluent tooling to version, deploy, and monitor your models.

```
Molti data scientists sanno cosa serve per utilizzare e addestrare un modello statistico automatizzato, il cosi detto detto machine learning model, ma potrebbe risultare difficile creare una strategia per implementare e mantenere tale modello. In questo meetup, scoprirai cosa sono le operazioni di apprendimento automatico (MLOps) nel machine learning, quali principi possono essere utilizzati per creare una strategia pratica MLOps e quali sono le attivitÃ  e le componenti coinvolte. Scopri come iniziare con vetiver, un framework per utilizzare MLOps in R (e Python!) che fornisce strumenti fluidi per la condivisione della versione scelta del modello finale, la distribuzione e il monitoraggio di tutti tuoi modelli.
```

title: Cross-Post for SoCal RUG: Building R Packages on Easy Mode
description:
## Details

*This event is cross-posted for SoCal RUG:*
Please RSVP at this link:
[https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/](https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/)

**\*\*Abstract\*\***
Do you have scattered R scripts recycled across projects? Have you had a simple R Markdown that escalated into a full suite of dashboards and reports? Do you look at old code you wrote and wonder what the heck you were trying to do? While there are obviously lots of benefits to packaging up your R code, creating your first R package is much easier than you may think.
In this session, we will create a working R package from scratch. We'll build and review a basic package skeleton with the help of the {devtools} package. Next, we'll showcase some best practices and iterative workflows around documentation and testing our new R package. Finally, we will also incorporate package data, vignettes, and a website with {pkgdown}.

RSVP:
[https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/](https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/)

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ - Chp14 - Support Vector Machines
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell! On Monday January 23, we will talk about Chapter 14 - Support Vector Machines.

The team spirit of this book club is really flowing and so this chapter will also be presented by one of our beloved co-organizers from R-Ladies Den Bosch, Martine Jansen.

**This book club:**
For this book club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (probably more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this book club, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna presented chapter 6, and Elena chapter 7 and 8! We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see [https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML](https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML).

title: Level up your Data Wrangling with Tidyverse
description:
**SPEAKER:**
Wanyin Li is the new organiser of R-Ladies Coventry.
She is a research student in Psycholinguistics and examine bilingual reading from the University of Birmingham. Before she started her PhD, she had zero experience in programming. With support and helps from her colleagues, R-ladies and other R communities, she learnt R language from scratch and has become an enthusiast R user.

**TOPIC OVERVIEW**
In this workshop, we will go through the most life-changing data wrangling tips Wanyin learned last year when she was analysing her data. These commands make it easy to get your data in exactly the right format, to summarise your data or make your workflows more reproducible. We will walk you through step by step. It will be friendly for beginners too.

**PREPARATION AND RESOURCES**
There is nothing to prepare in advance.

**ONLINE PROGRAMME**
The event will be held online and will start at 16:00 19th January 2023 (GMT).
Please join us via this Zoom link:
https://bham-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/85782804444?pwd=d0ZET1NjY3dJNlJhZ1Yybk85b1Fvdz09

**CODE OF CONDUCT**
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: haRd at woRk: flash talks on using R in the workplace
description:
Hello R-Ladies!

Mark your calendars for our first ever Flash Talk event on January 18th!! R is one of the most popular programming languages in the world and is used across many different industries, from research to healthcare and everything in between (check out some examples [here](https://www.rstudio.com/about/customer-stories/)).

Weâ€™ll be hearing from a handful of R-Ladies and learn how they use R in their professional work:

* **Andrea Blackburn** (Santa Barbara Zoo) & **Laura McMahon** (US Fish & Wildlife): *Using R to monitor and research wild California condor nesting patterns*
* **Summer Broeckx-Smith** (Geosyntec Consultants): *As You Wish! Using R Within Your Organizationâ€™s SOPs*
* **Daphne Virlar-Knight** (Arctic Data Center): *Curating Metadata with R*
* **Tanya Rogers** (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration): *Developing R packages to facilitate team collaboration and data access*
* **Jasmine Lai** (Aggregate Genius Inc.): *Building Shiny Applications*

This event is open to all R-users, from the R-curious to the R-obsessed, and will be held in-person at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS). Weâ€™ll begin our evening with a half-hour of mingling and light refreshments, then move into our intros and flash talks promptly at 6:00pm. Each flash talk will be 5 minutes long, followed by 5 minutes of Q&A.

**Getting to NCEAS:** We are located at 1021 Anacapa St. and the entrance to the building is accessed from City Lot #8 (see â€œMEDS Entranceâ€ [here](https://ucsb-meds.github.io/getting_to_nceas.html)). Itâ€™s free to park in the lot for the first 75 min, then $2.50 thereafter. There is also plenty of free parking on the surrounding streets.

We look forward to seeing you at NCEAS in the new year!

Your R-Ladies SB co-organizers,
Sam, An, Camila, & Danielle

**Please note:** While masks are currently optional, we kindly ask that if you are not feeling well that you please refrain from attending this event. We have a number of exciting events planned for the new year, so this certainly wonâ€™t be the last chance to learn about R with our community! Thank you.

title: Quarto/RMarkdown - What's Different?
description:
We are so excited to announce our next virtual meetup, which will serve as an overview of the difference between R Markdown and Quarto.

There will be endless opportunities for new meetups in 2023 that will help you to improve your skills within our community âœ¨

QuartoÂ® (https://quarto.org/) is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system built on Pandoc, which will allow you to create dynamic content with Python, R, Julia, and Observable. We are so pleased to be hosting Ted Laderas, PhD.

â¡ï¸ Place: Online on Zoom
â¡ï¸ Date/Time: January 12, 2023 from 7 pm to 8 pm CET

â¡ï¸ About the presentation:
Quarto is the next generation of RMarkdown, extending its capabilities beyond R to include Python, Julia, and Observable, as well as supporting advanced features of Shiny and HTML. As a seasoned RMarkdown user, you may have the question of whether you should switch to Quarto. In this presentation, I will help you answer this question for yourself by showing some of these new features of Quarto and how to get started with Quarto by adapting your R Markdown documents.

In order to validate your attendance, please register in advance for the meetup here ğŸ‘‰ https://tinyurl.com/2qovsvnj

title: Day in the Life of *Insert Data Role Here* Career Panel
description:
Join us for a career panel event where our panelists from various data careers will discuss their day-to-day jobs, training, and answer your questions. We will have break-out rooms for more specific discussion about the career youâ€™re interested in hearing more about.

**Tentative plan:**

* Panel introductions: names, job titles, education and training, job day to days, advice on how to get job/what skills to have/resources
* Moderator asks questions that were submitted by attendees when they registered
* Break out rooms: one room per speaker (or could have two speakers per room) where participants and panelists can have more direct and specific conversations about that career

**Panelists**:
Analytics Engineer: Marieke Jackson

DevOps/ML Ops: Isabel Zimmerman
Isabel Zimmerman is a software engineer on the open source team at Posit, where she works on building MLOps frameworks in Python. She is also currently pursuing a Master's degree in Data Science from Florida Polytechnic University. When she's not geeking out over new data science techniques, she can be found teaching her dog new tricks or baking vegan desserts.

Research Scientist/Data Analytics for Research Group: Julia Schuchard, PhD
Julia Schuchard has worked in health sciences research for over 10 years. For the past year she has served as Data Analytics Manager for PEDSnet, a national learning health system based at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia that uses electronic health record data to conduct clinical research studies. She has recently been on both sides of the hiring table (interviewing and being interviewed), which has reinforced how valuable coding skills are in today's job marketplace.

Data Scientist: Jessica Streeter
Jess is a Staff Data Scientist at Spring Health. She's never done an A/B test, hasn't created a predictive model in at least 2 years, and last did linear algebra in her freshman year of college. Somehow, she still seems to be a pretty good data scientist. She lives in Philly with her wife, two kids, and assorted 4 legged friends.

title: RLadies-Boulder #26: sparklyr - A Simple Guide w/ Hilary Traut
description:
**SAVE THE DATE!**
R Ladies is back after a hiatus and we are meeting in person at Solid State Depot in Boulder! We would love to see you all, get back together, socialize, and listen to Hilary's talk: sparklyr - A Simple Guide.

Ex-academic and current corporate nerd-for-hire Hilary Traut will provide a step-by-step guide to understanding Apache Spark in R. She'll tackle such existential questions as:

* What is Spark? What is it good for?
* When is Spark the tool for me?
* How to "spark" a connection to R
* Using dplyr and friends to simplify your spark modeling pipeline

Bring a laptop to follow along in real time, or just yourself to sit back and enjoy the presentation. Live coding mishaps practically guaranteed!

title: Introduction to Shiny Dashboards
description: This introduction to Shiny Dashboards will show users how to go from a raw data file to a working multi-Shiny app dashboard using the shinydashboard package. Topics such as interactivity, reactivity, appearance/themes, profiling, and deployment will be covered. This workshop is suitable for beginner to intermediate R users or for those who are new to dashboard and Shiny app development; former experience with Shiny is not necessary. Some familiarity with R and/or common visualization packages such as ggplot2 would be helpful and assumed but not required, so novice users are encouraged to attend

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ - Chp13 Deep learning
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell! In the first session of the new year, on Monday January 9, we will learn all about deep learning with neural networks!

Most machine learning models are shallow models: they only use a few layers of data transformations to reach the output representation. In contrast, **deep learning** uses many layers, where every additional layer creates a more elaborate representation. This results in complex models, for example used in image classification, speech recognition and autonomous driving.

Our presenter is **Galin Bajlekov**: a big fan of neural networks, long-time R user and R-Ladies supporter. He has a lot of experience with machine learning and data science, both in and outside of academia. Currently, he is a software engineer at [Enso](https://enso.org) (https://enso.org).

**This boook club:**
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (probably more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna presented chapter 6, and Elena chapter 7 and 8! We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see [https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML](https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML).

title: Creating an R Package: Why and How?
description:
Hello ,

Come and join us at our meetup â€œCreating an R Package: Why and How?â€ on Friday, January 6th from 6 - 8 PM to hear Dr. Heather Turner speak. This is a hybrid event.

The event will be held at the IIT-Madras Research Park (Hall 1, Block E) at Tharamani, Chennai. Please find the map at
https://goo.gl/maps/VpAeyWQTsdtYmv6B7

Zoom Meeting ID: 222 101 2022
Passcode: 2022

Dr. Heather Turner is a leader in the R and RSE communities, internationally recognized for contributions towards improving equality, diversity and inclusion (EDI). She is an established Research Software Engineer (RSE) in the field of Statistics, specializing in the R programming language. See more: https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/sci/statistics/staff/academic-research/turner/

We are part of R-Ladies, a worldwide organization that promotes diversity in the R community via meetups and mentorship in a friendly and safe environment. There are over 120 R-Ladies chapters around the world, and we are excited to be part of one here in Chennai.
